Mobile Video Productions, Inc. | network = [[National Geographic Channel]] (2004–11)
[[Nat Geo Wild]] (2011–12) | first_aired = {{Start date|2004|9|13}} | last_aired = {{End date|2012|9|15}} | num_seasons = 9 | num_episodes = 162 | list_episodes = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = ''Cesar 911'' | website = http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/wild/dog-whisperer/ }} '''''Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan''''' is a [[reality television]] series that featured dog trainer [[Cesar Millan]]'s work with problem dogs. After nine seasons, the series finale aired on September 15, 2012. Episodes of ''Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan'' featured guests' problem dogs, introduced through documentary-style footage and an interview with the owners. Millan offered suggestions on how the owners could become their pet's "pack leader", consistent with the theory that dogs are [[Pack (canine)|pack]] animals. He used behavior modification techniques and the philosophy that exercise, discipline, and affection are required "in that order" for dogs to be healthy and balanced.{{Cite news | last = Patterson | first = John | title = All heel for Cesar | newspaper = The Age | location = Australia | date = May 16, 2009 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/arts/all-heel-for-cesar/2009/05/14/1241894111287.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2 | accessdate =September 8, 2011 }} The series premiered on September 13, 2004, on the National Geographic Channel in half-hour episodes and in 2005 was expanded to one hour and moved to prime time. In 2011, the series aired its seventh season broadcast in more than eighty countries worldwide.{{Cite news | last = Oldenburg | first = Ann | title = Pack is back: A week of ''Whisperer'' | newspaper = USA Today | date = July 27, 2006 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2006-07-27-dog-whisperer_x.htm | accessdate =September 8, 2011}} Produced by Sheila Emery and [[Kay Sumner]] in association with [[MPH Entertainment, Inc.]] the program has an estimated audience of 11 million American viewers per week.{{Cite news | last = Wallace | first = Amy | title = Whispering to Rottweilers, and to C.E.O.'s | newspaper = The New York Times | location = USA | date = October 10, 2009 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/11/business/11dog.html?_r=2&pagewanted=1&%2359;dog%20whisperer&%2334&%2359&sq&st=cse&%2359;&scp=20 | accessdate =September 8, 2011 }} A number of entertainment-industry professionals have appeared on the program, including [[Virginia Madsen]] and [[Jada Pinkett Smith]]. In June 2014, [[Litton Entertainment]] announced a family-oriented revival/spinoff of the show, ''Dog Whisperer: Family Edition'', which airs on [[The CW Television Network|The CW]] Saturday mornings as part of Litton's [[One Magnificent Morning]] block. It began in October 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/the-cw-saturday-morning-block-litton-entertainment/|title=The CW Sets 5-Hour Saturday Morning Block|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=June 6, 2014}} ==Program format== ''The Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan'' is a documentary-style reality television program centering on animal behaviorist Cesar Millan{{cite news| first=Anushka | last=Asthana | title=This week we want to know all about Cesar Millan | newspaper =The Guardian | location=London | date= March 19, 2006 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/mar/19/anushkaasthana.theobserver | accessdate =September 8, 2011 }} as he works to rehabilitate dogs with behavior problems ranging from excessive barking, to behaviors that could leave the owners little choice but to medicate or euthanize their dogs if not corrected.{{cite web| title = Dog Whisperer: show overview | work = TV.com | url = http://www.tv.com/shows/dog-whisperer/| accessdate =September 11, 2011}}{{Cite journal | last = Eftimiades | first = Maria | title = Canine Controversy | journal = People | volume = 67 | issue = 3 | pages = 105–6 |date = January 2007| url= http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20062474,00.html | accessdate =September 8, 2011}} Millan said in a number of interviews that the program is not a guide to training, but a demonstration of his rehabilitation techniques. Each episode begins with the statement, "Do not attempt the techniques you are about to see without consulting a professional"{{cite web | title = Dog Whisperer: Cesar Down Under | publisher = Hulu.com| url = http://www.hulu.com/watch/141321/dog-whisperer-cesar-down-under | accessdate =September 8, 2011}} and repeats warnings that viewers should not attempt the behavior modification techniques at home. Viewers are introduced to the difficult dogs, and their owners, through home-movie style footage of their dogs engaging in the behavior its owners find problematic. A voice-over describes the situation briefly; the owners tell their story, and Millan arrives. Program publicity states that Millan does not review the "audition" videos of the dogs and has no advance knowledge of the situation unless the dog's behavior makes it a potential danger to Millan and the crew.{{cite journal| last= Idelson |first = Karen | title = Masters make case at 'Dog' auditions | journal = Variety |date = October 11, 2008|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117992066.html?categoryid=3238&cs=1&nid=2562 |accessdate=September 8, 2011}} Millan conducts an interview as the owners describe the issues at hand. Millan then usually offers suggestions on how the owners may alter their own habits to become a "pack leader" for their pet. He goes on to demonstrate behavior modification techniques with the dog and shows his expertise at establishing dominance over the troubled canine. Millan frequently brings one or more of his own dogs to a training session, which Millan describes as transferring another dog's "balanced energy." Sometimes, the dog is taken to his Dog Psychology Center where it stays with Millan's own dogs for days or weeks.{{cite news |last = Wyatt| first = Edward| title = A "Whisperer" Howl of Triumph, From the Curb Up | newspaper = The New York Times| location = New York|date = May 23, 2006| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/23/arts/television/23mill.html?pagewanted=2 | accessdate =September 8, 2011}} Each episode ends with a demonstration of the dog's altered behavior and the astonished pleasure of the owner. Episodes feature the owners and families whose dogs are being rehabilitated. In inviting submissions, the producers look for a wide variety of dog problems, including unusual phobias, obsessions, fearful behavior, aggression, or any other unique situations that Cesar could help transform. They ask owners for anything interesting or funny about their dog, and request a short video showing three instances of the problem behavior. Occasionally the program calls for particular types of dogs for themed episodes, such as "spoiled rotten" dogs for ''Beverly Hills Divas''.{{cite web | title = Show Submissions | work = Cesar's Way | url = http://www.cesarsway.com/node/836 | accessdate = April 10, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100403081114/http://www.cesarsway.com/node/836 | archivedate = April 3, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} On occasion ''Dog Whisperer'' is taken "on the road" with episodes recorded in U.S. cities other than Los Angeles, and from the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia.{{cite web|title = Cesar: on the road this week|work = Cesar's Way|publisher = Cesarsway.com|url = http://www.cesarsway.com/packgallery/photogallery/Cesar-Junior-in-Canada|accessdate = September 1, 2011|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110828122738/http://www.cesarsway.com/packgallery/photogallery/Cesar-Junior-in-Canada|archivedate = August 28, 2011|df = mdy-all}} ==History== {{update section|date=March 2015}} ''The Dog Whisperer'' chronicles the work of Cesar Millan, a [[Mexican American]], who runs a rehabilitation facility dedicated to the treating dogs with problematic behavioral issues. Millan spent his childhood in the city of Culiacan in the state of [[Sinaloa]], Mexico. However, his favorite place was his grandfather's ranch where he was captivated by the wild dogs on the property.{{Cite news|last=Gladwell |first=Malcolm |title=What the Dog Saw: Cesar Millan and the movements of mastery |newspaper=New Yorker |date=May 22, 2006 |url=http://www.gladwell.com/2006/2006_05_22_a_dog.html |accessdate=September 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120231428/http://www.gladwell.com/2006/2006_05_22_a_dog.html |archivedate=January 20, 2013 |df=mdy }} He spent so much time with the dogs that locals called him ''el perrero'' meaning "the dog boy". His fascination with dogs extended to television, and his favorite programs featured highly trained dogs such as [[Lassie's Rescue Rangers|Lassie]].{{cite web| title = Cesar Millan Biography | work = Encyclopedia of World Biography | url = http://www.notablebiographies.com/newsmakers2/2007-Li-Pr/Millan-Cesar.html | accessdate =September 12, 2011}} By his teens, Millan had decided that he wanted to be a Hollywood animal trainer, and he moved to Los Angeles, where he worked for a dog grooming store, and then for a limousine company. He ran a dog training business from a van before opening the iconic ''Dog Psychology Center'' in [[South Los Angeles]], where he focused on rehabilitating especially aggressive dogs.{{cite web| title = Biography of Cesar Millan| work = All-American Speakers| url = http://www.allamericanspeakers.com/celebritytalentbios/Cesar-Millan| accessdate =September 3, 2011}} His expertise with dogs was publicized primarily by word of mouth and Millan soon developed a clientele that included entertainment-industry professionals. Millan's first mention in the national mainstream media came in [[People (magazine)|People magazine]] in December 2002 in an article describing his work with action-film director [[Ridley Scott]]'s [[Jack Russell Terrier]]s. Millan is a self-taught dog trainer who established a reputation for working with aggressive breeds and hard to handle cases at a San Diego dog groomers,{{cite web| title = October 20, 2008 Immigrant of the Day: Cesar Millan (Mexico)| publisher = The Law Professors Blog.| quote =Millan gained a reputation as someone who could work easily with even the most difficult and aggressive of dogs. Millan's next job was washing limousines, work that had been offered to him by one of the San Diego clients. Millan changed his career goal from that of being a Hollywood dog trainer to rehabilitating troubled dogs and he started his own business, the Pacific Point Canine Academy| url = http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/immigration/2008/10/immigrant-of--3.html}}{{cite news| title = From the 'Dog Whisperer,' a Howl of Triumph| work= The New York Times | first= Edward | last = Wyatt| date= May 23, 2006|quote = Mr. Millan, 36, started by working in the early 1990's in a San Diego dog-grooming studio, where he gained a reputation for working well with the hard-to-handle cases. Through word of mouth, his ability to calm even the fiercest creatures spread north to Los Angeles.| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/23/arts/television/23mill.html}}{{cite web| title = Cesar Millan Announces The Dog Whisperer Tour for UK| publisher = Zimbio.com| quote = Prior to The Dog Whisperer series, Cesar Millan had focused on rehabilitating especially aggressive dogs and had operated the Dog Psychology Center in South Los Angeles (2002–2008)| url = http://www.zimbio.com/Cesar+Millan/articles/16Iu3gOYPtz/Cesar+Millan+Announces+Dog+Whisperer+Tour| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091121093718/http://www.zimbio.com/Cesar+Millan/articles/16Iu3gOYPtz/Cesar+Millan+Announces+Dog+Whisperer+Tour| archivedate = November 21, 2009| df = mdy-all}}{{cite web|title = All heel for Cesar|publisher = TheAGE.com.au, John Patterson, May 16, 2009| quote = He worked all the crappy jobs that besmirch the American Dream, until he got work as a dog groomer. His almost Zen-like demeanor with the most difficult of dogs soon caught the attention of, among others, actor Jada Pinkett ("before the Smith", Millan adds) and opened up a circle of her friends and co-celebs.| url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/arts/all-heel-for-cesar/2009/05/14/1241894111287.html}} subsequently developing a celebrity clientele. In 2002, after he was profiled in a newspaper article, Millan received offers from a number of producers, and chose to work with Sheila Emery and Kay Sumner. They teamed with [[MPH Entertainment, Inc.]], which had been involved in successful reality-based cable shows, to produce a pilot. The producers had preliminary talks with Animal Planet, but the Network would not commit beyond a single pilot episode.{{Cite journal | last = Milio | first = Jim |author2=Melissa Jo Peltier |author3=Mark Hufnail | title = Dog Whisperer Real Reality TV | journal = HighDef Magazine | url = http://www.highdef.com/index.php/2006/03/dog-whisperer-real-reality-tv/ | date = March 15, 2006}} The National Geographic Channel expressed interest in the program, ordering 26 half-hour episodes, on the proviso that MPH provide the required deficit financing. Under this agreement MPH and Emery/Sumner retained the copyright to the show. The channel retains control of television distribution in the United States and Canada. MPH and Emery/Sumner control worldwide home video and foreign sales and share that revenue with the channel, allowing them to create and market various video collections.{{Cite news | last = Wyatt | first = Edward | title = From the ''Dog Whisperer'', a Howl of Triumph | newspaper = The New York Times | location = USA | date = May 23, 2006 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/23/arts/television/23mill.html?pagewanted=1&sq&st=cse%22&scp=4%22dog%20whisperer}} The name of the program was similar to [[Paul Owens (dog trainer)|Paul Owens']] 1999 book ''The Dog Whisperer''. Owens, a reward-based trainer, has distanced himself from the program and now calls himself "the original dog whisperer".{{Cite news | last = Sternberg | first = Andy | title = The Original Dog Whisperer | work = USC Annenberg Radio News | url = http://annenbergradio.org/index.php/main/storypage/the_original_dog_whisperer | date = October 19, 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081120183800/http://annenbergradio.org/index.php/main/storypage/the_original_dog_whisperer | archivedate = November 20, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} The show premiered in 2004, gradually gaining audience attention, by word of mouth. For the first season, the series wasn't positioned in [[prime time]] and the channel did little to promote the show. However, in Season 2 it was expanded to an hour and moved to a prime time slot. In 2009 the National Geographic Channel agreed with Fox to syndicate the series in the Fall of 2010, bringing it to a channel with exposure to approximately 50 million of the USA's 120 million households. A journalist for ''[[The Times]]'' questioned Cesar Millan on his motivation for producing the program, and quoted him as responding, "The goal that God and I have together is the whole world transformed through a dog."{{Cite news | last = Whipple | first = Tom | title = Enter the Dog Whisperer, with Stern Words for Our Dogs | newspaper = The Times | location = London | date = March 1, 2010 | url = http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article7044473.ece}} In 2006, former [[publicist]] Makeda Smith{{Cite news | author = Ann Oldenburg| title = Pack is back: A week of 'Whisperer' | newspaper = USAToday.com | date = July 28, 2005 | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/1085090461.html?dids=1085090461:1085090461&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+28%2C+2006&author=Ann+Oldenburg&pub=USA+TODAY&desc=Pack+is+back%3A+A+week+of+'Whisperer'&pqatl=google}} filed a [[copyright infringement]] [[lawsuit|suit]] which stated that in 2001, she and her partner [[brand]]ed Millan as "The Dog Whisperer" by conceiving, producing and directing what they say was a pilot named "The Dog Whisperer", featuring [[Tichina Arnold]].{{Cite news | author = N.A. | title = Famed Dog Whisperer Cesar Millan Sued For Five Million | newspaper = WKTV News Online | location = Utica, New York | date = May 1, 2006 | url = http://www.wktv.com/news/entertainment/2723596.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110927171512/http://www.wktv.com/news/entertainment/2723596.html | archivedate = September 27, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} The $5,000,000 lawsuit was settled out of court. During the program's fourth season, the show celebrated its centennial episode. The program is broadcast in more than eighty countries worldwide, where it is alternatively known as ''Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan'', ''Dog Whisperer'', or ''The Dog Whisperer''. At the debut of the sixth season of the ''Dog Whisperer'', a New York Times article estimated an audience of 11 million American viewers each week. In 2011, following the start of its seventh season, all repeats and future episodes were moved to [[Nat Geo WILD]]. The ninth and final season of Dog Whisperer began airing in July 2012; with Millan going on to star in the 12-part series ''Leader of the Pack'' in 2013.{{cite web | url = http://www.cesarsway.com/dogwhisperer/Dog-Whisperer-with-Cesar-Millan-Final-Season | title = The Final Season of Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan | accessdate = July 26, 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120719163707/http://www.cesarsway.com/dogwhisperer/Dog-Whisperer-with-Cesar-Millan-Final-Season | archivedate = July 19, 2012 | df = mdy-all }} The following year, Millan's new series ''Cesar 911'' debuted on Nat Geo Wild, with the first episode airing March 7, 2014. While not a direct continuation of ''The Dog Whisperer'', it focuses on his continuing work with troubled dogs. ==Daddy== {{main|Daddy (dog)}} Daddy was an [[American Pit Bull Terrier]] integral to Millan's work and the show.{{Cite news|last=Jasen |first=Lee |title=Top dawgs: Smart shopping for a trainer can lead to well-behaved pets |newspaper=Deseret News |location=Salt Lake City |date=April 27, 2008 |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,695273605,00.html |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720052918/http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,695273605,00.html |archivedate=July 20, 2008 |df=mdy }} Daddy was originally owned by rapper [[Redman (rapper)|Redman]]. Daddy became known for his calm temperament, tolerance for smaller dogs, and capacity for empathy.{{cite web | title = Daddy | work = Cesar's Way | publisher = Cesarsway.com | url = http://www.cesarmillaninc.com/packprofiles/dpc_daddy.php | accessdate = August 1, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090929140928/http://www.cesarmillaninc.com/packprofiles/dpc_daddy.php | archivedate = September 29, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} Millan employed Daddy's temperament to rehabilitate dogs, train dog owners, and serve as a role model for a breed often associated with aggressiveness. Daddy appeared frequently in episodes of the ''Dog Whisperer'',{{cite news|last=Johnston |first=Lauren |title='Dog Whisperer' Cesar Millan's pit bull sidekick Daddy dies at age 16 |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=February 23, 2010 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/lifestyle/pets/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_dog_whisperer_cesar_millans_pit_bull_sidekick_daddy_dies_at_age_16.html |accessdate=September 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225001402/http://www.nydailynews.com/lifestyle/pets/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_dog_whisperer_cesar_millans_pit_bull_sidekick_daddy_dies_at_age_16.html |archivedate=February 25, 2010 |df=mdy }} with Millan referring to him as his ''right-hand man''.{{cite web | title = In Memoriam: Daddy the Pit Bull | work = Cesar's Way | publisher = Cesarsway.com | url = http://www.cesarsway.com/news/daddy-memoriam | accessdate = February 21, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100223051849/http://www.cesarsway.com/news/daddy-memoriam | archivedate = February 23, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} According to Millan, Daddy "never made a mistake — never, never. He's never displayed aggression or any other negative behavior. He's just always helped me."{{cite web | title = Daddy: The Early Years | work = Cesar's Way | publisher = Cesarsway.com | url = http://www.cesarsway.com/packgallery/packprofiles/daddy-the-early-years | accessdate = February 21, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100222103626/http://www.cesarsway.com/packgallery/packprofiles/daddy-the-early-years | archivedate = February 22, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} In 2009, Millan added "I have never had a dog like Daddy. I've been astounded by his intuition, consoled by his affection, and awed by his silent empathy."{{cite web| last = Sung| first = Helena| title = 'Dog Whisperer' Cesar Millan and His Pit Bull, Daddy| work = Paw Nation | date = October 23, 2009 | url = http://www.pawnation.com/2009/10/23/dog-whisperer-cesar-millan-and-his-pitbull-daddy/| accessdate =September 3, 2011}} ==Celebrity appearances== [[Jada Pinkett Smith]], who helped Millan achieve his goal of having a television show, participated in the program's 100th episode{{Citation |last = Oh |first = Eunice | title = 5 Things You Didn't Know about Cesar Millan |work = People Pets| url=http://www.peoplepets.com/news/celebrities/5-things-you-didn-t-know-about-cesar-millan/1 |date = October 8, 2009 | accessdate =March 22, 2010}}{{cite web | last = Sutton | first = Larry | title = Jada Pinkett Smith Takes the Lead | work = Cesar's Way | publisher = Cesarsway.com | date = July 25, 2011 | url = http://www.cesarsway.com/magazine/hollywood-hounds/jada-pinkett-smith-takes-the-lead | accessdate = August 17, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110818183454/http://www.cesarsway.com/magazine/Hollywood-Hounds/Jada-Pinkett-Smith-Takes-the-Lead | archivedate = August 18, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} along with other celebrity guests including [[Patti LaBelle]],''Dog Whisperer, Season 1, Episode 15'' [[Virginia Madsen]],''Dog Whisperer, Season 3, Episode ?'' [[Ed McMahon]]''Dog Whisperer Season 4, Episode 6'' and [[Daisy Fuentes]]''Dog Whisperer, Season 1, Episode 6''{{cite web| last = McDonough | first = Kevin | title = Tune in Tonight: Reformed canines salute their 'Whisperer'| work = [[Reading Eagle]] Arts & Entertainment | date = September 19, 2008| url = http://readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=106470 | accessdate =September 3, 2011}}—all having worked with Millan on earlier episodes with their dogs. {| style="margin:auto; valign=top; border:2px solid black; width:80%; margin:0 0 0.5em 1em;" class="collapsible collapsed" ! style="font-size:120%; text-align:center;" | Celebrity  Appearances |- |[[Robert B. Weide|Bob Weide]] |Jake |Season 1, Episode 14 |Jake and King |- |[[Jackie Zeman]] | Goldie | Season 1, Episode 20 | Pepsi and Goldie |- | [[Daisy Fuentes]] | Alfie. |Season 1, Episode 26 | Boyfriend and Alfie |- | [[Denise Richards]] | Betty, Lucy and Hank |Season 2, Episode 8 |Wild Things |- | [[Phil Jackson]] and [[Jeanie Buss]] | Princess | Season 2, Episode 11 | LA Laker Meltdown |- | [[Mike White (filmmaker)|Mike White]] | Tootsie and Ginger | Season 4, Episode 3 |Kiko, Tootsie & Ginger, and Binkey |- | [[Kathy Griffin]] |Chance and Pom-Pom |Season 4, Episode 27 |My Life on the Dog List |- |[[Jada Pinkett Smith]], [[Patti LaBelle]], [[Virginia Madsen]], [[Ed McMahon]] and Daisy Fuentes. |100 rehabilitated dogs |Season 4, Episode 32 |100th Episode Celebration |- |[[Jillian Michaels (personal trainer)|Jillian Michaels]] | Seven |Season 6, Episode 5 |Hairy Houdini |- |[[Howie Mandel]] |His wife's dog |Season 7, Episode 1 | Mandel's Big Deal |- |[[Missi Pyle]] and [[Casey Anderson (naturalist)|Casey Anderson]]. |Ellie & J.J. |Season 7, Episode 3 | Ellie & J.J. and Oscar |- |[[Rhona Mitra]] | Oscar |Season 7, Episode 5 |Honeymoon Hell |- |[[Hugh Hefner]] | Willa & Charlie |Season 9, Episode 7 |Playboy Playmates |- |[[Kelsey Grammer]] | George & Elvis |Season 9, Episode 11 |Hollywood Hounds |} ==Production crew== The writers of ''Dog Whisperer'', Jim Milio and [[Melissa Jo Peltier]], write that they put on their "writer-producer hats to focus, restructure, and help create a theme for the segment". This is followed by the "shaping of the show itself,' writing the [[Narrator|narrations]], [[:wikt:wrap|wraps]], [[Teaser campaign|teasers]], [[Tag (advertisement)|tags]], and [[Bumper (broadcasting)|bumpers]]. They went on to say that "this is all for a show where absolutely nothing in the field (save Cesar's arrivals to the dog owner's front doors) is fabricated ... what we like to call the last 'real' Reality show on television."{{Cite journal | last = Milio | first = Jim | last2 = Peltier | first2 = Melissa Jo | title = Does Reality Still Bite? | journal = Written By: The Magazine of the American Writers' Guild, West | url = http://www.wga.org/writtenby/writtenbysub.aspx?id=3412 | date = March 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110606041610/http://www.wga.org/writtenby/writtenbysub.aspx?id=3412 | archivedate = June 6, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} Executive producers for MPH Entertainment are Jim Milio, [[Melissa Jo Peltier]], and Mark Hufnail. Sheila Possner-Emery and Kay Bachman-Sumner are producers. For National Geographic Channel, the executive producer is Char Serwa. Nicholas Bunker is associate producer, Christina Lublin coordinating producer and SueAnn Fincke series producer. The series is directed by SueAnn Fincke and Jim Milio. Cinematographers are Bryan Duggan and Christopher Komives. Thirty-six other crew members are involved in location management, sound recording, camera operation, music, editing, and production assistance.{{cite web | title = Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan | work = The Internet Movie Database | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0423642/fullcredits | accessdate =April 6, 2010 }} ==Reception by peers== In February 2006, an article in the ''New York Times'' quoted Dr. Nicholas Dodman, director of the Animal Behavior Clinic at [[Tufts University]]'s [[Cummings School of Veterinary Medicine]], said that his college had "written to National Geographic Channel and told them they have put dog training back 20 years".{{cite news | title = C'mon, Pooch, Get With the Program | publisher = The New York Times, Anna Bahney, February 23, 2006 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/23/fashion/thursdaystyles/cmon-pooch-get-with-the-program.html?pagewanted=2 | date=February 23, 2006 | accessdate=April 28, 2010}} A ''New York Times'' August 2006 [[op-ed]] by [[Mark Derr]], an author noted for his publications on dogs, criticized ''Dog Whisperer'' for its reliance on a "simplistic view of the dog's social structure". According to Derr, Millan's methodology "flies in the face of what professional animal behaviorists—either trained and certified veterinarians or ethologists—have learned about normal and abnormal behavior in dogs".{{cite news|last=Derr|first=Mark|title=Pack of Lies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/31/opinion/31derr.html|accessdate=August 13, 2011|date=August 31, 2006|newspaper=New York Times}} His theory of dominance in domestic dogs has been described as flawed.[http://4pawsu.com/dogpsychology.htm Flaws in dominance theory] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405000000/http://4pawsu.com/dogpsychology.htm |date=April 5, 2016 }} Also in 2006, the [[American Humane Association|American Humane Association (AHA)]] requested that the National Geographic Channel stop airing the program,{{cite journal | url = http://www.spokanimal.org/Newsletter9-06forweb.pdf | title = Dog Whisperer Training Approach More Harmful Than Helpful | last = Blauvelt | first = R | volume = 23 | issue = 3 | publisher = SpokAnimal C.A.R.E. | year = 2006 | pages = 1–2 | format = PDF | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080227095116/http://www.spokanimal.org/Newsletter9-06forweb.pdf | archivedate = February 27, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} saying that training tactics shown on ''Dog Whisperer'' were inhumane, outdated and improper.{{cite web | last = Torgerson, DVM, MBA | first = Bill | title = 'Dog Whisperer' Training Approach More Harmful Than Helpful | work = AHA Press Release | date = September 6, 2006 | url = http://beyondcesarmillan.weebly.com/aha-american-humane-assoc.html | accessdate =January 30, 2010 }} By November 2009, Millan had invited the American Humane Association to the set of ''Dog Whisperer,'' at which time, according to Millan, "they changed their state of mind about what is cruel".{{cite news | title = Cesar Millan talks about UK tour | publisher = BBC, November 27, 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/gloucestershire/hi/things_to_do/newsid_8383000/8383225.stm | date=November 27, 2009}} The association announced in February 2010 that despite "sharp differences of view in the past" and some lingering areas of disagreement, they shared many areas of interest with Millan.{{cite web | author = American Humane Association | url = http://www.americanhumane.org/about-us/newsroom/news-releases/dog-training-symposium.html | title = American Humane Association Convenes Humane Dog Training Symposium | date = February 12, 2010 | accessdate = March 24, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100326050007/http://www.americanhumane.org/about-us/newsroom/news-releases/dog-training-symposium.html | archivedate = March 26, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} Debra Horwitz, president of the American College of Veterinary Behaviorists, said that the major benefits of ''The Dog Whisperer'' are that it makes owners aware that they are not alone in the problems they have with their pets, and that it provides good advice on the need for dogs to exercise and have rules. But, Horwitz adds, the show also has the major drawback of attributing behavior problems to dominance when the dog may be misbehaving because it is fearful or anxious.{{Citation | last = Yin | first = Sophia | author-link = Sophia Yin | title = Clinical Report: Dealing with outdated behavior recommendations | journal = Veterinary Forum | volume = 24 | issue = 12 | date = December 2007 | url = http://askdryin.com/movies/VFDec2007.pdf }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Pet columnist Steve Dale said in a July 2010 newspaper column that while he believed Millan was "blessed with an amazingly intuitive understanding of dog behavior," some of the methods shown on the program, particularly those related to [[dominance (ethology)|dominance]], were inappropriate and not substantiated by science.{{Cite news | last = Dale | first = Steve | title = Dog Whisperer Has His Good, and Bad Points | newspaper = Tribune Media Service | date = July 14, 2010 | url = http://www.adn.com/2010/07/14/1367284/dog-whisperer-has-his-good-and.html | accessdate = August 7, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110111193530/http://www.adn.com/2010/07/14/1367284/dog-whisperer-has-his-good-and.html | archivedate = January 11, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} The [[Humane Society of the United States]] [[Genesis Awards|Genesis Award]] Committee presented Milan with a 2008 Special Commendation for his work in rehabilitating animals. Dr. [[Sophia Yin]], a veterinarian, researcher and animal behaviorist, wrote articles and spoken about Cesar Milan's television show and methods, calling Cesar Milan's methods "based on the erroneous understanding of dominance and the need to use force or coercions [sic] as the first-line of training for all problems". She did, however, point out in the same sentence that "there are some good recommendations and lessons one can learn from it and other shows", and went on to list them.{{cite web|title=The Dominance Controversy|url=http://drsophiayin.com/philosophy/dominance}} ==Ratings== The Dog Whisperer premiered in 2004 as a half-hour program but subsequently became first in the National Geographic channel ratings and was expanded to a [[prime-time]], one hour format.{{Cite news | last = Flaim | first = Denise | title = Bad doggie medicine? ; Veterinarians bark at the way 'Dog Whisperer' dispenses 'tough love' | newspaper = Chicago Tribune | location = Chicago, Ill| page = 1 | date = May 23, 2006 | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/1040605001.html?dids=1040605001:1040605001&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+23%2C+2006&author=Denise+Flaim%2C+Tribune+Newspapers%3A+Newsday+%22Dog+training%2C+by+the+book%22+information+box+by+Lilah+Lohr&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Bad+doggie+medicine%3F+%3B+Veterinarians+bark+at+the+way+'Dog+Whisperer'+dispenses+'tough+love'&pqatl=google | accessdate =September 10, 2011 }} In 2007, the network renewed its most popular series to that date with an unprecedented 35 episodes in which Milan travelled the show to US cities like New York and Miami.{{cite news | last = Dempsey | first = John | title = National Geographic greenlights specials | newspaper = Variety | date = March 19, 2007 | url =http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117961415?refCatId=14 | accessdate =September 3, 2011 }} In 2008, the show in its 100th episode had grown from an estimated 100,000 households per episodes per household to an estimated 1,000,000 people per episode.{{cite news | last = Wood | first = Deborah | title = 100 episodes later, "Dog Whisperer" still leading the pack | newspaper = Seattle Times | date = September 19, 2008 | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/television/2008188562_tvdog19.html | accessdate =September 3, 2011 }} By 2010 Dog Whisperer had been the National Geographic's top rated series for six years.{{Citation| author = PR Newswire | title = New One-Hour Drama, and One-Hour Reality Series Featuring ATF Being Simultaneously Readied for Cable Nets | newspaper = Sys-Con Media | date = October 4, 2010 | url = http://www.sys-con.com/node/1557607| accessdate =September 3, 2011 }} ==Awards== In 2005 and again in 2007, Millan was awarded the ''Michael Landon Award for Inspiration to Youth Through Television''.[http://www.youngartistawards.org/specials28.html Young Artists Awards.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308103354/http://www.youngartistawards.org/specials28.html |date=March 8, 2014 }}. The show received [[Emmy]] nominations for Outstanding Reality Program in both 2006 and 2007, though it did not take the award on either occasion.{{Citation | author = Associated Press | title = Complete list of Emmy nominations | journal = Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | url = http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06188/703915-237.stm | date = July 7, 2006}}{{Cite journal | last = Bruno | first = Mike | title = Emmy Nominees: The Class of 2007 | journal = Entertainment Weekly | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20045108_20045123_20047121,00.html | date = July 18, 2007 }} In 2008, ''Dog Whisperer'' won ''TV Best Variety or Reality Show'' at the 23rd Annual [[Imagen Awards|Imagen Foundation Awards]], and also won the ''People's Choice Award for Favorite Animal Show'' that same year.{{Citation | last = Witzeman | first = Jeff | title = Cesar Millan: Changing The World One Dog Owner At A Time | journal = The Huffington Post | date = January 25, 2010 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeff-witzeman/cesar-millan-changing-the_b_432052.html }} ''Dog Whisperer'' again won the [[36th People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]] in the category of Favorite Animal Show in 2010.{{cite web | author = RT Staff | title = Awards Tour: 2010 People's Choice Awards Winners! | publisher = Rotten Tomatoes | url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10010667-hangover/news/1863543/comments/all/awards_tour_2010_peoples_choice_awards_winners | date = January 6, 2010 | accessdate =April 30, 2006 }}[http://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2010/01/full-list-of-peoples-choice-awards-2010-winners/ Full List of People's Choice Awards 2010 Winners - The Hollywood Gossip] In 2010, the show was nominated for the [[Directors Guild of America Award]] for ''Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Reality Programs'' but did not take the awards. ==See also== * ''[[It's Me or the Dog]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/wild/dog-whisperer/ ''Dog Whisperer'' official website] * [http://cesarsway.com/ Cesar Millan official website] * {{IMDb title|0423642}} * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0423642/episodes IMDb Episode List] {{National Geographic TV}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dog Whisperer, The}} [[Category:National Geographic Channel programs]] [[Category:Television shows about dogs]] [[Category:Dog training and behavior]] [[Category:Dogs in popular culture]] [[Category:Dog-related professions and professionals]] [[Category:American reality television series]] [[Category:2004 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:2012 American television series endings]]

{{no footnotes|date=January 2013}}{{Infobox person |name=Ephraim Sklyansky |image=Sklyansky.jpeg |caption= |birth_date=August 12/July 31, 1892 |birth_place=[[Fastiv]], [[Ukraine]] |death_date={{death date|1925|8|27|mf=y}} |death_place=[[Long Lake, New York]] }}
'''Ephraim Markovich Sklyansky''' ({{lang-ru|Эфраим Маркович Склянский}}) ({{OldStyleDate|August 12|1892|July 31}} - August 27, 1925) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] revolutionary and statesman. He joined the [[Bolsheviks]] during his years as a student in the medical faculty of [[Kiev University]], from which he graduated in 1916; he was immediately drafted into the army, where he served as a doctor and became prominent in the clandestine military organizations of the Bolsheviks. At the time of the [[October Revolution]] he was a member of the [[Military Revolutionary Committee]] of the [[Petrograd Soviet]]; on meeting him in November, [[Leon Trotsky]] was so impressed with his "great creative ''élan'' combined with concentrated attention to detail" that he appointed him his deputy on the [[Revolutionary Military Council]], where he served with distinction during the [[Russian Civil War]] (1918-1920) and helped improve the fighting condition of the [[Red Army]]—Trotsky called him the [[Lazare Carnot|Carnot]] of the Russian Revolution. In 1924 his position as Trotsky's deputy was taken over by [[Grigory Zinoviev]]'s ally [[Mikhail Frunze]]. Instead, he was made chairman of the Mossukno state textile trust, and the following May he left on a tour of Germany, France, and the United States to acquire technical information. On August 27, 1925 he died in a boating accident on [[Long Lake (New York)]] along with {{Interlanguage link multi|Isay Khurgin|ru|3=Хургин, Исай Яковлевич}}, the first head of [[Amtorg Trading Corporation]]. The high-ranking Soviet defector [[Boris Bazhanov]] was convinced that Sklyansky had been drowned on [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin's]] orders, and the alleged accident had been organized by {{Interlanguage link multi|Georgy Kanner|ru|3=Каннер, Григорий Иосифович}} and [[Genrikh Yagoda]].<ref>[[David W. Doyle]], ed. ''Bazhanov and the Damnation of Stalin''. Ohio University Press (1990), p. 66.</ref>

'''Erediauwa''' (22 June 1923 – 2016) was the 39th [[Oba of Benin]], [[Nigerian traditional rulers|traditional ruler]] of the [[Edo people]] in [[Benin City]], [[Edo State]], Nigeria.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Benin) |first1=Erediauwa (King of |title=I Remain, Sir, Your Obedient Servant |date=2004 |publisher=Spectrum Books |isbn=9789780293826 |url=https://books.google.bg/books/about/I_Remain_Sir_Your_Obedient_Servant.html?id=znp0AAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y |accessdate=30 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Formerly known as Prince Solomon Akenzua, Oba Erediauwa's full title was ''His Royal Majesty Omo n'Oba n'Edo Uku Akpolokpolo Erediauwa I''. He was succeeded by [[Ewuare II]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nwaubani |first1=Adaobi Tricia |title=Opinion A Voodoo Curse on Human Traffickers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/24/opinion/sunday/voodoo-curse-human-traffickers.html |accessdate=30 August 2018 |work=New York Times |date=March 24, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
Oba Erediauwa took on the title and duties as traditional head of state and rightful heir of the extinct [[Benin Empire]] when he was crowned, succeeding his father, Oba [[Akenzua II]], in a ceremony held in Benin City, Nigeria, on 23 March 1979.<ref name=guardosawe>{{cite web |url=http://www.edo-nation.net/osawe1.htm |title=25 Years Of An Oba |author=Ambrose Osawe |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=29 March 2004 |accessdate=10 September 2010}}</ref>
==Biography== Erediauwa was born on 22 June 1923, son of Oba [[Akenzua II]]. Before being crowned he was known as Prince Solomon Aiseokhuoba Igbinoghodua Akenzua. He attended [[Government College, Ibadan]] (1939–1945), then [[Yaba College]], before going to [[King's College, Cambridge]] to study Law and Administration. He joined the Eastern Nigeria Civil Service in 1957 as a District Officer, later moving to the Federal Civil Service where he retired as Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Health in 1973. For a short period he was the regional representative of [[Gulf Oil]]. In 1975, he was appointed Commissioner for Finance in [[Bendel State]] during the Military Administration of Major-General [[George Agbazika Innih]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Oba Urediauwa I (1923-2016) |url=http://www.pressreader.com/nigeria/daily-trust/20160510/282222304969423 |work=Daily Trust |date=10 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=guardosawe/> Ascending to the throne on 23 March 1979, Erediauwa celebrated his 30th anniversary in 2009. During this period, he several times acted as a peacemaker between politicians. For example, he intervened in a dispute between [[Abia State]] governor [[Orji Uzor Kalu]] and [[Tony Anenih]], Chairman of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] Board of Trustees, and resolved another face-off involving Anenih and former [[Edo State]] Governor [[Lucky Igbinedion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200903230873.html |title= Oba Erediauwa Marks 30 Years on Benin Throne |work=Vanguard |author=Simon Ebegbulem |date=23 March 2009 |accessdate=10 September 2010}}</ref> Apart from the ceremonial aspects, his 30th anniversary festival was a week long carnival and a showcase of Benin arts and culture, with numerous performances of traditional music and dance, as well as an art exhibition and food fair.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/ArtsandCulture/Art/5398161-146/story.csp |title = Oba Erediauwa’s 30th coronation anniversary |author = patience saduwa |date = 10 September 2010 |work = Next |accessdate = 10 September 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100203121507/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/ArtsandCulture/Art/5398161-146/story.csp |archivedate = 3 February 2010 |df = dmy }}</ref> His death was announced on 29 April 2016. The statement did not say when and how he died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://punchng.com/breaking-benin-monarch-oba-erediauwa-passes/|title=BREAKING: Benin monarch, Oba Erediauwa, passes on|author=Zovoe Jonathan|date=29 April 2016|work=Punch Newspapers|accessdate=29 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/headlines/202635-oba-of-beninomo-noba-nedo-uku-akpolokpolo-is-dead.html|title=Oba of Benin, Omo n’Oba n’Edo Uku Akpolokpolo, is dead - Premium Times Nigeria|author=|date=|work=Premium Times Nigeria|accessdate=29 April 2016}}</ref>
==Public Image== In Benin the Oba is considered to be the only representative of the supreme deity and is considered a god in his own right. He is believed to be ordained by cosmic consent. This means the people considered him to have have the ability to either venerate or curse a community, so although he ruled with respect and kindness for his people they also feared him.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Osagie |first1=Otabor |title='How Oba Erediauwa cursed our community' - The Nation Nigeria |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/oba-erediauwa-cursed-community/ |website=The Nation Nigeria |accessdate=30 August 2018 |date=22 March 2018}}</ref>
Erediauwa's media friendly image increased the royal family's engagement with the Benin Kingdom and Nigeria in general. Previously approached with apprehension by the public and media practitioners, the gates of the palace were opened, which normalised communication with the Oba's subjects through a quarterly press conference.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Uche |first1=Atuma |title=Life and times of Oba Erediauwa – - The Sun News |url=http://sunnewsonline.com/life-and-times-of-oba-erediauwa/ |website=The Sun News Ng |accessdate=30 August 2018 |date=30 April 2016}}</ref>

Friedrich Alexander Georg Luger | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = }} [[File:Patent US753414 - Georg Luger Recoil Loading Small Arms.pdf|thumb|right|Georg Luger's 1900 patent on the [[Luger pistol]].]] '''Georg Johann Luger''' (March 6, 1849 – December 22, 1923) was an [[Austria-Hungary|Austrian]] designer of the famous [[Luger pistol]] and the [[9×19mm Parabellum]] [[cartridge (firearms)|cartridge]]. ==Early life and military service== Georg Luger was born in [[Steinach am Brenner]], [[County of Tyrol|Tyrol]] to Dr. Bartholomaeus von Luger, a surgeon. After Georg's birth, his family moved to Italy, where Dr. Luger taught at the [[University of Padua]]. Georg grew up with Italian as his second mother tongue and finished ''[[Grundschule]]'' ([[primary school]]) and ''[[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]]'' ([[university-preparatory school]]) in [[Padua#Austrian rule|Austrian]] [[Padua]]. After graduation, his parents sent him to Vienna, where he studied at the ''Wiener Handelsakademie'' (Vienna Commercial Academy), the predecessor to today's [[Vienna Business School]]. In October 1867, Luger volunteered for military service as a Reserve Officer Cadet with the {{ill|78th Infantry Regiment (Austria-Hungary)|lt=78th Infantry Regiment|de|K. u. k. Infanterieregiment „Albrecht von Württemberg“ Nr. 73}}. He was promoted to ''Cadett-Corporal'' (Officer Cadet Corporal) on June 1, 1868, and to ''Faehnrich'' (Ensign) on October 1. Luger's good [[marksman]]ship brought him to the attention of his superiors; he was sent to the Austro-Hungarian [[Military Firearms School]] at Camp Bruckneudorf, where he soon became an instructor. There, his interest in automatic loading systems began. In 1871 Luger was promoted to ''Leutnant der Reserve'' ([[lieutenant]]) and moved to the military reserve. ==Family== Luger married Elisabeth Josefa Dufek in 1873. He moved to Vienna with her and they had three children (in order): *''Georg Franz Luger'' *''Julius Wilhelm Bartholomaeus Luger'' (born March 16, 1880) *''Friedrich Alexander Georg Luger'' (born April 26, 1884) Luger's first son, Georg Franz, became a civil engineer and joined his father in military weapons development. His second son fell as a Hauptmann d.R. (Reservist Captain) in [[World War I]] on the Galician front in 1915. ==After the military== After leaving the military, Luger worked as an accountant and later in the management of the Jockey Club, one of the top social meeting points in Vienna. He met [[Ferdinand Mannlicher|Ferdinand von Mannlicher]] in about 1875 and the two collaborated on rifle magazine designs, which seemed to awaken a latent talent for design within Luger. In 1891 Luger was employed by [[Ludwig Loewe & Company]] (of [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]) and gradually became a consultant designer. In 1894 he was sent to demonstrate a [[Hugo Borchardt]]-designed weapon, manufactured by [[Deutsche Waffen und Munitions Fabriken]] (DWM) (which had evolved from Loewe after its founder's death), to the [[US Army]]. The Army rejected [[Borchardt C-93|the pistol]], but from criticism he received, Luger improved it, creating the [[Luger pistol|Parabellum pistol]] (commonly called a Luger), and patenting it in 1898. This pistol was a success for both Luger and DWM. Luger's contract with DWM was cancelled in 1919 and he successfully sued them over [[patent]] [[royalties]]. However Luger had lost all his savings by this time. ==Bibliography== * ''Imperial Lugers'' by Jan C. Still (Still's Books, 1994) * ''Third Reich Lugers'' by Jan C. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Gérard Depardieu | honorific_suffix = [[National Order of Quebec|CQ]] | image = Gérard Depardieu Cannes 2015 3.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = Depardieu at the [[2015 Cannes Film Festival]] | birth_name = Gérard Xavier Marcel Depardieu | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1948|12|27}} | birth_place = [[Châteauroux]], France | citizenship = French, Russian, Algerian | occupation = Actor, filmmaker, businessman, vineyard owner | years_active = 1964–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Élisabeth Depardieu|Élisabeth Guignot]]|1971|1996}} | partner = [[Carole Bouquet]] ({{abbr|c.|cohabited}} 1997; {{abbr|separated}} 2005)
Clémentine Igou ({{abbr|c.|cohabited}} 2005-present) | children = 4, including [[Guillaume Depardieu|Guillaume]] and [[Julie Depardieu|Julie]] }} '''Gérard Xavier Marcel Depardieu''' ({{IPA-fr|ʒeʁaʁ dəpaʁdjø|lang|fr-Gerard_Depardieu.ogg}}; born 27 December 1948) is a French actor. He is one of the most prolific character actors in film history, having completed more than 170 films since 1967.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} He has received acclaim for his performances in ''[[The Last Metro]]'' (1980), for which he won the [[César Award for Best Actor]], in ''[[Police (1985 film)|Police]]'' (1985), for which he won the [[Volpi Cup for Best Actor]], ''[[Jean de Florette]]'' (1986), and ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (1990 film)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'' (1990), winning the [[Cannes Film Festival]] for [[Best Actor Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actor]], his second [[César Award for Best Actor]], and his first [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for Best Actor. He co-starred in [[Peter Weir]]'s comedy ''[[Green Card (film)|Green Card]]'' (1990), winning a Golden Globe Award and later acted in many big budget [[Hollywood]] movies including [[Ridley Scott]]'s ''[[1492: Conquest of Paradise]]'' (1992), [[Kenneth Branagh]]'s ''[[Hamlet (1996 movie)|Hamlet]]'' (1996), [[Randall Wallace]]'s ''[[The Man in the Iron Mask (1998 film)|The Man in the Iron Mask]]'' (1998), and [[Ang Lee]]'s ''[[Life of Pi (film)|Life of Pi]]'' (2012). He is a Chevalier of the [[Légion d'honneur]] and Chevalier of the [[Ordre national du Mérite]]. He was granted [[Citizenship of Russia|citizenship]] of [[Russia]] in January 2013, and became a cultural ambassador of [[Montenegro]] during the same month. ==Early life== Gérard Depardieu was born in [[Châteauroux|Châteauroux, Indre]], France. He is one of the five children of Anne Jeanne Josèphe (née Marillier) and René Maxime Lionel Depardieu, a metal worker and volunteer fireman.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/74/Gerard-Depardieu.html |title=Gerard Depardieu Biography (1948–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |accessdate=26 February 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://genindre.org/arbpdf/depardieu.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030112220/http://genindre.org/arbpdf/depardieu.pdf |archivedate=30 October 2008 |title=Les ancêtres de Gérard Depardieu (1948) }} After leaving school at the age of thirteen, he worked at a printworks. He also became involved in selling stolen things, and was put on probation at one point.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2005/sep/04/houseandgarden.books |title=Voulez-vous poulet avec moi? |last1=Atkin |first1=Tim |date=4 September 2005 |website=The Observer |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=27 April 2014}} ==Acting career== [[File:Gérard Depardieu Cannes 1994.jpg|thumb|upright|Depardieu at the [[1994 Cannes Film Festival]]]] At the age of sixteen, Depardieu left Châteauroux for [[Paris]]. There, he began acting in the new comedy theatre [[Café de la Gare]], along with [[Patrick Dewaere]], Romain Bouteille, [[Sotha (actress)|Sotha]], [[Coluche]], and [[Miou-Miou]].[http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/scene/theatre/30-ans-toutes-ses-dents_498236.html 30th Anniversary of Café de la Gare], [[L'Express (France)|L'Express]], 15 August 2002, (in French) He studied dancing under Jean-Laurent Cochet. His first film role to gain attention was playing Jean-Claude in [[Bertrand Blier]]'s comedy ''[[Going Places (1974 film)|Les Valseuses]]'' (''Going Places'', 1974).[https://www.imdb.com/list/9baDvZc-KPA/ Gérard Depardieu at IMDb] Other prominent early roles include a starring role in [[Bernardo Bertolucci]]'s historical epic ''[[1900 (film)|1900]]'' (1976), with [[Robert De Niro]], and a role in [[François Truffaut]]'s ''[[The Last Metro]]'' (1980), with [[Catherine Deneuve]] for which he won his first [[César Award for Best Actor]]. His international profile rose as a result of his performance as a doomed, hunchbacked farmer in the film ''[[Jean de Florette]]'' (1986) and received notice for his starring role in ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (1990 film)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'' (1990), for which he won his second [[César Award for Best Actor]], the [[Cannes Film Festival]] for [[Best Actor Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actor]], and received a nomination for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]]. Depardieu co-starred in [[Peter Weir]]'s English language romantic comedy ''[[Green Card (film)|Green Card]]'' (1990), for which he won a Golden Globe Award. He has since had other roles in other English language films, including [[Ridley Scott]]'s ''[[1492: Conquest of Paradise]]'' (1992), [[Kenneth Branagh]]'s ''[[Hamlet (1996 movie)|Hamlet]]'' (1996), and [[Ang Lee]]'s ''[[Life of Pi (film)|Life of Pi]]'' (2012). He played [[Obelix|Obélix]] in the four live-action ''[[Asterix films (live action)|Astérix]]'' films in which he is said to have discovered [[Mélanie Laurent]] when she was fourteen.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/europe/this-europe-confessions-of-depardieu-597202.html |title=This Europe: Confessions of Depardieu |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=10 February 2003 |accessdate=26 February 2010 |first=John |last=Lichfield |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117012434/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/europe/this-europe-confessions-of-depardieu-597202.html |archivedate=17 January 2009 }} In 2009, he took part in a rare performance of Sardou's ''[[La Haine (drama)|La Haine]]'' at the Festival de Radio France et Montpellier Languedoc Roussillon, with [[Fanny Ardant]]; subsequently broadcast on [[France Musique]].[http://www.festivalradiofrancemontpellier.com/2009/19-la-haine-ardant-depardieu-onm.php Presentation of concert on Festival de Radio France site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214164556/http://www.festivalradiofrancemontpellier.com/2009/19-la-haine-ardant-depardieu-onm.php |date=14 December 2013 }} In 2013, he starred in an independent film titled ''[[A Farewell to Fools]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/monterey-media-acquires-us-and-canada-rights-to-no-god-no-master-redwood-highway-and-a-farewell-to-fools|title=Monterey Media Acquires Three Films, Including Works Starring Gerard Depardieu and Harvey Keitel |publisher=indiewire.com|date=17 October 2013|accessdate=6 November 2013}} Depardieu featured as a main character in [[Antwerp]] ([[Edinburgh Festival]] 2014), a play in The Europeans Trilogy ([[Bruges]], Antwerp, [[Tervuren]]) by Paris-based UK playwright [[Nick Awde]]. ==Personal life== [[File:Gérard Depardieu Carole Bouquet 2001.jpg|thumb|upright|Depardieu with [[Carole Bouquet]] at the [[2001 Cannes Film Festival]]]] In 1970, Depardieu married [[Élisabeth Depardieu|Élisabeth Guignot]], with whom he had two children, actor [[Guillaume Depardieu|Guillaume]] (1971–2008) and actress [[Julie Depardieu|Julie]] (born 1973). On 28 January 1992, while separated from Guignot, he had a daughter, Roxanne, with the model Karine Silla (sister of producer [[Virginie Besson-Silla]]). In 1996, he divorced Guignot and began a relationship with actress [[Carole Bouquet]], who was his partner from 1997 to 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.dhnet.be/culture/people/article/128735/bouquet-depardieu-en-crise.html |title=Bouquet — Depardieu en crise |publisher=Dhnet.be |date=31 August 2005 |accessdate=26 February 2010}} [[File:Gérard Depardieu Cannes 2015 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Depardieu at the [[2015 Cannes Film Festival]]]] On 14 July 2006, he had a son, Jean, with French-Cambodian Hélène Bizot (daughter of [[François Bizot]] and not to be confused with actress [[Hélène Bizot]]).Issue 3089, 31 July 2008, [[Paris Match]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2011042248640/Siem-Reap-Insider/upheaval-of-life-blamed-on-apsara.html |title=Upheaval of life blamed on Apsara |work=The Phnom Penh Post |location=Cambodia |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=25 April 2011 |first1=Michael | last1=Sloan}} Since 2005, Depardieu has lived with Clémentine Igou. He underwent heart surgery in July 2000.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/829186.stm |title=Depardieu has heart surgery |work=BBC News |date=11 July 2000 |accessdate=25 April 2018}} On 13 October 2008, Depardieu's son Guillaume died from [[pneumonia]] at the age of 37. The infection arose as a complication following surgery to amputate his leg. Guillaume's health had been adversely affected by drug use. A motorcycle crash resulted in a number of post-accident operations performed in an attempt to save the leg. These were complicated by the development of post-operative wound infections, eventually necessitating the amputation of the leg.{{cite news |first=John |last=Lichfield |title=Gérard Depardieu's son dies of pneumonia at 37 |date=14 October 2008 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/grard-depardieus-son-dies-of-pneumonia-at-37-960265.html |work=The Independent |accessdate=3 January 2013}} In his sixties, Depardieu attracted attention from the media and legal authorities for his behavior. On 16 August 2011, he urinated in a bottle while on board a [[CityJet]] flight bound for [[Dublin]] as it taxied in [[Paris]]. The incident was attributed to [[urinary incontinence]] caused by a [[prostate]] problem with the [[flight attendant]] not allowing him to get up from his seat to go to the toilet because the aircraft was already moving.{{cite news|last1=Samuel|first1=Henry|title=Gerard Depardieu's plane incident down to prostate problems|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/8709223/Gerard-Depardieus-plane-incident-down-to-prostate-problems.html|accessdate=12 May 2017|work=The Telegraph}} In August 2012, he was accused of assault and battery for punching a motorist in Paris.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/aug/17/gerard-gepardieu-accused-road-rage-assault |title=Gérard Depardieu accused of punching motorist in road rage assault |author=Henry Barnes |work=The Guardian|date=17 August 2012}} In November 2012, he was arrested for driving while intoxicated after he fell from his scooter, and was found to have a blood alcohol level of 1.8 grams per litre, well above the French limit for driving of 0.5.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2240547/French-actor-Gerard-Depardieu-arrested-driving-scooter-drunk-Paris-following-minor-accident.html |title=French actor Gerard Depardieu 'arrested for driving scooter drunk' in Paris following minor accident |author=Kimberley Dadds |date=29 November 2012 |work=DailyMail}} [[File:Gérard Depardieu and Vladimir Putin, Sochi, Russia, 2013-01-06 1.jpeg|thumb|upright|Depardieu with Vladimir Putin in [[Sochi]], Russia, 5 January 2013]] He has been an official resident of [[Néchin]], [[Belgium]], since 7 December 2012.{{cite web|last=Fraser |first=Christian |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20760572 |title=Depardieu: French film star stirs tax row |publisher=BBC News |date=17 December 2012|accessdate=25 January 2013}} French prime minister [[Jean-Marc Ayrault]] criticised his move.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20691889|title=Depardieu tax exile move 'shabby' - French PM Ayrault |work=[[BBC]] |date=12 December 2012 |accessdate=17 December 2012}} On 15 December 2012, Depardieu publicly stated he was handing back his French passport.{{cite news |title=Depardieu 'to give up passport' in tax exile row |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20750593|publisher=BBC news |date=16 December 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.lejdd.fr/Politique/Actualite/Gerard-Depardieu-Je-rends-mon-passeport-581254 |date=15 December 2012 |work=lejdd.fr |title=Gérard Depardieu : "Je rends mon passeport"}} On 3 January 2013, Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] signed an Executive Order granting Russian citizenship to Depardieu.{{cite news|title=Executive Order on granting Russian citizenship to Gerard Depardieu|url=http://eng.kremlin.ru/news/4833 |date=3 January 2013 |publisher=Russian Presidential Executive Office}} In his first interview thereafter, Depardieu attacked Putin's critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/01/20131145231670149.html |title=Depardieu attacks Russia's opposition. |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date= |accessdate=25 January 2013}} In his autobiography, Depardieu said Putin "immediately liked my hooligan side."news.com.au 6 October 2104 [http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity-life/gerard-depardieu-reveals-he-was-a-child-prostitue-in-revealing-autobiography-it-happened-like-that/story-fn907478-1227081952070 putin liked depardieus hooligan side at once] In February 2013, he registered as a resident of [[Saransk]]. Also in January 2013, he was appointed a cultural ambassador for [[Montenegro]].{{cite web |url=http://french.ruvr.ru/2013_01_09/Depardieu-ne-sest-pas-presente-a-sa-convocation-et-est-devenu-ambassadeur/ |title=Depardieu nommé ambassadeur de la culture du Monténégro |author= |date=9 January 2013 |website=La Voix de la Russie |accessdate=27 April 2014}} During the summer of 2015, due to Russian-Ukrainian political issues, Depardieu was banned from television and movie theaters in Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/gerard-depardieu-movies-banned-theaters-tv/story?id=32995523 |title=Why Gerard Depardieu Movies Have Been Banned From Theaters, TV - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=10 August 2015 |accessdate=25 April 2018}} In August 2018, he was accused of the sexual assault and rape of a young female actress. Via his lawyer, Depardieu denied the allegations.{{cite news|last=Chrisafis|first=Angelique|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/aug/30/french-inquiry-opens-after-gerard-depardieu-accused-rape|title=French investigation opens after Gérard Depardieu accused of rape|work=The Guardian|date=30 August 2018|accessdate=30 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-45360902|title=Gérard Depardieu: French actor accused of rape|accessdate=30 August 2018}} ==Awards== Depardieu has been nominated for the Best Actor in a Leading Role [[César award|César]] 17 times during his career and won it twice, in 1981 and 1991. Harvey "Drew" Peltier, III
Mary Ellen Peltier |relations=[[Harvey Peltier Sr.]] (father)
John Mitchell Crum (son-in-law) |religion =[[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholic]] |branch= |footnotes= }} '''Harvey Andrew Peltier Jr.''' (January 18, 1923 – December 5, 1980),{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/74254108|title=Harvey A. Peltier Jr.|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} was from 1964 to 1976 a member of the [[Louisiana State Senate]] from District 21, which included [[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana|Lafourche]] and [[Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana|Terrebonne]] [[County|parishes]] in [[South Louisiana]]. He served alongside [[Claude B. Duval]], senator from Terrebonne and [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana|St. Mary]] parishes.{{cite web|url=http://senate.la.gov/Documents/Membership/Documents/SenateMembership1880ForwardRevisedMar2011.pdf|title=Membership in the Louisiana State Senate, 1880-Present|publisher=senate.la.gov|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} Peltier resided in his native [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]], [[Louisiana]]. At the age of twenty-five, he was a delegate to the [[1948 Democratic National Convention]] held in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], which nominated the [[Harry Truman|Truman]]-[[Alben Barkley|Barkley]] ticket.{{cite web|url=http://klax-tv.com/2014-la-political-hall-of-fame-inductees-selected/|title=2014 LA Political Hall of Fame Inductees Selected, September 27, 2013|publisher=[[KLAX-TV]]|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} He was appointed in 1975 by [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Edwin Edwards]] as a trustee of the [[University of Louisiana System]] and was its first president from 1975 until his death in 1980.{{cite web|url=http://www.ulsystem.net/index.cfm?md=newsroom&tmp=detail&articleid=74&printer=1|title=History|publisher=ulsystem.net|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}''The Chacahoula'' [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] yearbook, 1976, p. 300 Peltier's father, [[Harvey Peltier Sr.]], an attorney, banker, and horse breeder,{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/74253714|title=Harvey Peltier Sr.|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} a political confidante of and a campaign manager for [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] and [[U.S. Senator]] [[Huey Long|Huey Pierce Long Jr.]]{{cite web|url=http://si.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1079050/index.htm|title=Pot Of Gold For A Nervy Cajun, September 19, 1966|publisher=si.com|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} was a member of the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] from 1924 to 1929{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf|title=Membership of the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812-Current|publisher=house.louisiana.gov|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} and held the same senate seat as his son, from 1930 to 1940. Peltier Sr. also served on the former Louisiana State Board of Education as the elected member from [[Louisiana's 3rd congressional district]].''The Lagniappe'', [[Louisiana Tech University]] yearbook, 1970, p. 32 Peltier's mother was the former May Ayo (1902-1992). He had a sister, Bernice P. Harang, and three brothers, Donald Louis Peltier (1926-2008), Richard Benton Peltier (1938-2007),{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/20797578|title=Richard Benton Peltier|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=October 17, 2013}} and Dr. James R. Peltier (born 1930), a member of the Louisiana State University Board of Supervisors.{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/74254426|title=Mary Ayo Peltier|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} Peltier's brother-in-law, Warren Harang Jr. (1921–2005), was a former president of the Thibodaux [[Chamber of Commerce]] and the American Sugar Cane League, a member of the [[Lafourche Parish School Board]], and the mayor of Thibodaux from 1968–1978, 1986–1990, and 1994–1998.{{cite web|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/la/terrebonne/obits/2005/0511/warrenharangjr.txt|title=Katina A. Gaudet, Former Thibodaux mayor died this morning at 84, November 2, 2005|publisher=usgwarchives.net|accessdate=October 17, 2013}} In 1945, Peltier married Irma Mary Geheeb (1924-2014), the third daughter of Albert John and Cleo Belou Geheeb. Known as "Mickey", she graduated from the former Ursuline College, now [[Ursuline Academy (New Orleans)|Ursuline Academy]], in her native [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]]. The Peltiers lost an infant son in 1952 and have three surviving children, Patricia P. Crum, Harvey "Drew" Peltier III, and wife Linda, and Mary Ellen Peltier.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/theadvocate/obituary.aspx?n=irma-mary-mickey-geheeb-peltier&pid=171416553&fhid=14161#sthash.Dzs07ufX.dpuf|title=Irma Mary "Mickey" Geheeb Peltier|publisher=''[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|Baton Rouge Morning Advocate]]''|accessdate=June 22, 2014}} Peltier's son-in-law, John Mitchell Crum (1945-2012), was a [[district attorney]] of the 40th Judicial District of [[St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana|St. John the Baptist Parish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/houmatoday/obituary.aspx?pid=157470501#sthash.Bd0aqMYn.dpuf|title=John Crum obituary, May 4, 2012|publisher=''[[The Houma Courier]]''|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} The Peltier family is interred in the family tomb at St. Joseph Cemetery in Thibodaux. In February 2014, four months before the death of his wife, Peltier Jr. was [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] inducted into the [[Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame]] in [[Winnfield, Louisiana|Winnfield]]. Peltier's colleague in the Louisiana House, [[Dick Guidry|Richard P. "Dick" Guidry]] of Lafourche Parish, was inducted in the same ceremony. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Louisiana|Politics|Education}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before =A. O. Lucy Seton-Watson | parents = [[Robert William Seton-Watson]] | website = | footnotes ={{Cite ODNB|id=101031670|title=Watson, (George) Hugh Nicholas Seton-}}{{Cite web | last = Saxon | first = Wolfgang | title = PROF. HUGH STETON-WATSON, 68 – HISTORIAN OF EASTERN EUROPE | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/22/obituaries/prof-hugh-steton-watson-68-historian-of-eastern-europe.html | publisher = NY Times | date = 22 December 1984 | accessdate = 21 December 2013 }} }} '''George Hugh Nicholas Seton-Watson''' [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (15 February 1916 – 19 December 1984) was a British historian and [[political scientist]] specialising in Russia. ==Early life== Seton-Watson was one of the two sons of [[Robert William Seton-Watson]], the activist and historian. He was educated at [[Winchester College]] and [[New College, Oxford]], from where he graduated in 1938. ==War-time activities== After working for the British [[Foreign Office]] in Belgrade and [[Bucharest]] at the start of the [[Second World War]], Seton-Watson joined the British [[Special Operations Executive]]. Interned by the Italians after the fall of Yugoslavia to the Axis in 1941, Seton-Watson was repatriated to Britain, and later posted to the British [[special forces]] in Cairo, where he remained until 1944. In January 1944 he moved to [[Istanbul]] where he performed intelligence activities among the refugees coming from the Balkans.Stephen Dorril, ''MI6: Inside the Covert World of Her Majesty's Secret Intelligence Service'', Touchstone, 2002 p.60 ==Academic career== Seton-Watson wrote most of his first major work, ''Eastern Europe between the Wars, 1918–1941'' in [[Cape Town]] while on his way from Italy to Britain after the fall of Yugoslavia, finishing it in Cairo during the battle of [[El Alamein]] in 1942. In 1945 he was appointed [[praelector]] in politics at [[University College, Oxford]]. In 1951 he was appointed to the chair of Russian history at the [[University of London]], where he remained until 1983, exercising a major influence over British and American understandings of Russia during the [[Cold War]]. He subsequently became the Professor Emeritus of Russian history. Beginning in 1957 at [[Columbia University]], he regularly visited institutions in the United States to lectures and conduct research. During a three-month fellowship, beginning in October 1984, at the [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]] he became ill with pulmonary problems and was admitted to [[Georgetown University Hospital]] where he died three weeks later. ==Work== After publishing ''The Decline of Imperial Russia, 1855–1914'' in 1952, Seton-Watson published his most famous work, ''The Russian Empire, 1801–1917'' in 1967. This became the standard history of late imperial Russia for a generation.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} Seton-Watson's ''Nations and States: an Enquiry into the Origins of Nations and the Politics of Nationalism'' (1977) made a fundamental contribution to the study of nationalism, though later overshadowed by the success of [[Benedict Anderson]]'s more theoretical ''[[Imagined Communities]]''. The ''[[New York Times Book Review]]'' called him "the outstanding authority on the satellite countries of Eastern Europe". ==Honors== Seton-Watson received a DLitt from Oxford in 1974 and an honorary doctorate from the University of Essex in 1983. In the [[1981 New Year Honours]] he was appointed [[CBE]]. ==Works== * ''Eastern Europe between the wars'' (Cambridge Univ. Press, 1945) * ''Neither War Nor Peace: The Struggle for Power in the Postwar World'' (Frederick A. Praeger, 1960) * ''The new imperialism: A background book'' (Bodley Head, 1961) * ''Nationalism and communism: essays, 1946–1963'' (Methuen, 1964) * ''Nationalism old and new'' (Methuen, 1965) * ''The Russian empire 1801–1917'' (Clarendon, 1967) [https://archive.org/download/in.ernet.dli.2015.110576/2015.110576.The-Russian-Empire-1801-1917.pdf online] *''The ’sick heart’ of modern Europe: the problem of the Danubian lands'' (University of Washington Press, 1975) * ''The imperialist revolutionaries: trends in world Communism in the 1960s and 1970s'' (Stanford: Hoover Institution Press, 1979.) * ''Nations and states: an enquiry into the origins of nations and the politics of nationalism'' (Methuen, 1977) * ''The imperialist revolutionaries'' (1979) * ''Language and national consciousness'' (Oxford University Press, 1981) * ''The making of a new Europe: R.W. Seton-Watson and the last years of Austria-Hungary''. With Christopher Seton-Watson (Methuen, 1981) * ''The decline of Imperial Russia 1855–1914'' (Westview Press, 1985). * ''The East European revolution'' (Westview Press, 1985) * ''From Lenin to Khrushchev : the history of world communism'' (Westview Press, 1985) * ''R.W. Seton-Watson and the Roumanians, 1906–20'' (2 vols, Editura Ştiinţifică şi Enciclopedică, Bucureşti, 1988) ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Internet Archive author |sname=}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seton-Watson, Hugh}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century British historians]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Western writers about Russia]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]] [[Category:Scholars of nationalism]]
