{{Infobox person |image = |image_size = |alt = |birth_date = 1937 |birth_place = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] |death_date = {{Death date and given age|2001|5|28|~64}} |death_place = [[Washington D.C.]], [[United States]] |death_cause = [[Liver disease]] |resting_place_coordinates = |nationality = Egyptian |known_for = General Counsel to the [[World Bank]] |education = BA in Law, PhD in International Law |alma_mater = [[Cairo University]] Law School, [[Harvard Law School]] |spouse = Samia S Farid |children = Sharif, Yasmine and Nadia |awards = }} '''Ibrahim F.I. Shihata''' (1937–2001) was an expert on [[international development]] and general counsel of the [[World Bank]] from 1983 to 1998. Dr. Ibrahim F.I Shihata was the Founder of the Opec Fund and Senior Vice President and General Counsel at the World Bank for 20 years.
==Early life and education== At the age of 20, Ibrahim Shihata graduated with a BA in law from [[Cairo University]] Law School at the top of his class. He originally planned to continue his education in the [[United States]], but then received an offer from the Conseil d’Etat to work as a legal advisor in the Ministry of Health.
In the following year, he was moved to the technical bureau of the President of the Conseil. During [[Egypt]] and [[Syria|Syria's]] failed unification, he was seconded to the office of the President of the Republic. During his tenure, a senior official fell ill, and recommended Ibrahim Shihata take his place in drafting the constitution of the United Arab Republics. Although working full-time, he managed to complete two graduate diplomas, earning distinctions on both.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gentile|first=Carmen|title=The Man with the Plan|url=http://new.enigma-mag.com/interview_archives/?p=294|publisher=Enigma Magazine|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
During his service with the then Unified Republic, Dr. Shihata was informed that he had been granted a scholarship for study in the United States. He had only applied to [[Harvard University]], where he completed his PhD in International Law. He completed the degree in 1964, in just under 4 years. His professor spoke highly of his dissertation, stating that the paper increased the value of a PhD degree from Harvard, and the value of the university as a whole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bibalex.org/unl/Frontend/ISAUC.aspx |title=ISAUC – Ibrahim Shihata Arabic UNL Center |publisher=Bibalex.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-16}}</ref>
==Early professional career== Upon completion of his PhD, Dr. Shihata returned to Egypt to teach at [[Ain Shams University]] at both undergraduate and graduate levels. Two years later, he was offered a position to work as Legal Counsel of the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic development. He worked as legal counsel in the role, based in Kuwait, for eight years.
==The OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID)== Dr. Shihata was appointed as Director General of the then [[OPEC Special Fund]] at its creation in 1976. Under his leadership, the OPEC Special Fund developed into the long-standing institution that is known as today—the [[OPEC Fund for International Development]] (OFID). During his tenure, Dr. Shihata was known for his contribution towards addressing the issue of poverty, primarily in the southern areas of the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ofid.org/NewsPress/tabid/87/ArticleId/187/Dr-Ibrahim-Shihata-former-Director-General-of-the-OPEC-Fund-died-on-May-28-aged-63.aspx |title=Dr. Ibrahim Shihata, former Director-General of the OPEC Fund, died on May 28, aged 63 |publisher=Ofid.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-16}}</ref>
While working at OFID, Dr Shihata also served as an Executive Director at the [[International Fund for Agricultural Development]]. He was the first Chairman of the [[International Development Law Institute]] he contributed establishing in 1983.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Liber Amicorum Ibrahim F.I. Shihata. International Finance & Development Law|last=Sabine Schlemmer-Schulte Ko-Yung Tung|first=|publisher=Brill Nijhoff|year=2001|isbn=9789041114792|location=La Hague|pages=IDLI: A New Model for NGO Structure, Sustainability and Growth; M. Hager.}}</ref>
==World Bank== In 1983, Dr Shihata was appointed as Senior Vice President & General Counsel for the [[World Bank]] and Secretary-General of the [[International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes]] (ICSID). He was handpicked by then President, Tom Clawsen, and was the first person from a developing country to be appointed to the position.
Dr. Shihata is most well known for his creation of the [[Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency]] (MIGA) Organisation. Founded in 1985, the purpose of the organisation was to encourage direct foreign investment to developing countries for economic development, while providing insurance against non-commercial risks such as war and famine. He made a significant contribution to the [[Global Environment Facility]] (GEF) a joint program with the United Nations that promoted environmentally friendly development. He was responsible for the expansion of the [[International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes]] (ICSID). During his 17-year tenure at the World Bank, Dr. Shihata developed these organisations into world-renowned entities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wolfensohn|first=James D|title=Obituary |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/537/ec3.htm|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> Dr. Shihata was known for his achievements as general counsel, and the numerous books and articles he authored on the World Bank, international law and international economics. He wrote his famous book (in Arabic) about Egypt, ''Waseyati Li Beladi'' (My Will for My Country), which analyized Egypt's major problems at the time and predicted the Egyptian Revolution.
==Retirement and death== Dr. Ibrahim Shihata retired in 2000 as Senior Vice-President and Special Adviser to the World Bank's President. On May 28, 2001, Dr. Ibrahim Shihata died in [[Washington D.C.]], from complications due to liver disease.

{{Infobox person |name = Israel Shochat |native_name = ישראל שוחט |image = Israel Shocat.jpg |image_size = 300px |birth_date = January 30, 1886 |birth_place = [[Lyskovo]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_date = July 7, 1962 (Aged 75) |death_place = [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]] }} '''Israel Shochat''' ({{Lang-he-n|ישראל שוחט}};1886–1962) was a founder of and a key figure in [[Bar-Giora (organization)|Bar-Giora]] and [[Hashomer]], one of the precursors of the [[Israel Defense Forces]].
==Biography== Israel Shochat was born in 1886 in Lyskovo, in the [[Grodno Governorate]] of the [[Russian Empire]] (present-day [[Belarus]]). As a child, he had tutors for [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]. At age 18, he was involved in a Jewish defence group and in [[Poale Zion]]. He went to [[Germany]] to study [[agronomy]] but left his studies after only three months and immigrated to [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] with his brother, Eliezer, in 1904. They worked as field hands in the fields and orchards of [[Petah Tikva]]. He moved to [[Rishon LeZion]] to work in the winery. There Israel met [[Alexander Zaïd]] and shared with him his radical [[socialist]] ideas. Zaid received them enthusiastically and declared "I'm with you, for life or death, let's start as of now!"<ref>"Anshei Hashomer" Gershon Gera</ref> In Rishon LeZion, he suffered the first bout of fever, which was to plague him for the remainder of his life.
Israel Shochat moved to [[Jerusalem]] to persuade the [[Yeshiva|yeshivot]] leaders to join the efforts to create a national workforce. His attempts failed. To support himself, he shined shoes at [[Jaffa Gate]]. As a result of ill health, he was forced to give up manual labour and worked as [[Israel Belkind]]'s assistant. He became interested in the [[Circassians]] living in Palestine, as an example of how a small minority could preserve its identity and pride in an often hostile environment. The key for Shochat was that they cultivated their land and protected it with their own hands.
Along with [[Israel Giladi]], [[Alexander Zaid]] and [[Mendel Portugali]], he convinced some of the Jewish farmers to let them help with guarding the fields. It was a modest start. Israel represented [[Poalei Zion]] in the [[Zionist Congress]] of 1907, which took place in [[the Hague]] in the [[Netherlands]]. He was his party's first representative from Palestine. He was unable to present his idea to the assembly and in a private conversation, [[Menachem Ussishkin]] told Israel that he was much too young to succeed in achieving the goal of a national defence. [[Yitzhak Ben-Zvi]], a representative from the [[United States]] [mistake, YBZ was from Russia and emigrated to Palestine that very year, 1907; somebody please figure this out], was receptive and they travelled back to Palestine together, working along the way.
In 1907, Israel Shochat was one of the 10 people who, in Yitzhak Ben-Zvi's [[Jaffa]] apartment, founded [[Bar-Giora (organization)|Bar-Giora]], a clandestine organisation which sought to create an armed Jewish force. It took its name from one of the leading [[Bar Giora|Jewish rebels]] of the [[First Jewish–Roman War]]. [[Manya Shochat|Manya Wilbuszewicz]], the leader and founding member of the collective at [[Ilaniya|Sejera]], convinced Shochat to join the agricultural settlement there. He accepted, becoming the second leader of the community which he used as a base for training Jewish guards. In May 1908, Israel and Manya got married. The next year, Israel and Manya Shochat were among the leading founders of [[Hashomer]] (lit. ''The Watchman"), a more ambitious enterprise than Bar-Giora, being the first attempt to provide an organised defence for all the Jewish communities in Palestine.
In 1914 the [[Ottoman Empire]] entered [[World War I]]. The Turkish authorities viewed the Jews of Palestine with a great degree of distrust, particularly Russian nationals like the Shochats; after the Shochats were found hiding weapons for the Hashomer organisation, they were deported to the Anatolian city of [[Bursa, Turkey|Bursa]], in Turkey. While their first-born soon, Gideon ("Geda"), had been born in Palestine during their first years of marriage, their daughter Anna was born in Anatolia in 1916.
The Shochat family returned to Palestine around [[Passover]], 1919, after attending the [[Poale Zion|Poalei Tziyon]] convention in [[Stockholm]]. They both joined the [[Ahdut HaAvoda]], a workers' party led by [[David Ben-Gurion]]. At first Israel Shochat worked the land in [[Kfar Giladi]], but soon became involved in founding the famous [[Gdud HaAvoda|Work Battalion]] and in organizing the defence of the [[Galilee]]. In 1920 the Ahdut HaAvoda decided to replace the existing [[Hashomer]] militias with a new organisation, the [[Haganah]], established as the paramilitary arm of the [[Histadrut]].<ref>Peri, Yoram. "Between battles and ballots. Israeli military in politics." Cambridge University Press. 1983. {{ISBN|0-521-24414-5}}. Page 26.</ref> During the [[Jaffa riots|riots of 1921]], Israel Shochat took an active part in defending [[Tel Aviv]] and Jaffa. The same year his wife left for the United States on mission to collect money for the Histadrut and, rather on her own initiative, for the Haganah. Due to political opposition within the Jewish community, she only managed to raise several thousand dollars, which she sent to Israel Shochat who was waiting in [[Vienna]], where he oversaw the purchase and shipment of weapons to the now British-administered [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]].
In the years 1921–26, Israel Shochat was on the [[Jewish National Council]]. He was also instrumental in forming [[Hapoel]]. In the 1930s, after a long conflict with the Histadrut, he retired from political life. He died in 1962 and is buried in [[Kfar Giladi]] alongside his wife.

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2016}} {{Orphan|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jahnabi Goswami | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|9|16|df=y}} [[Nagaon]], [[Assam]] [[India]] | occupation = HIV/AIDS activist | nationality = [[India]]n | residence = [[Guwahati]], [[India]] }} '''Jahnabi Goswami''' (born 16 September 1976) is an Indian [[HIV/AIDS]] activist from [[Assam]]. She is the first woman in the Northeast to declare her HIV status. She is the founder and current treasurer of Assam Network of Positive People (ANPP) and the current president of the Indian Network for People living with HIV/AIDS (INP+), the first women to hold the position.<ref name="Infochange">{{cite web|url=http://infochangeindia.org/hiv-aids/living-with-hiv/a-positive-approach.html|title=Info Change India - Page Not Found|website=infochangeindia.org}}</ref>
==Early life==
Jahnabi Goswami grew up in Kampur, [[Nagaon]]. Her father Hiranya Goswami was killed by [[ULFA]] militants in 1990. She was married off to a wealthy business man at the age of 17 in the winter of 1994. Her husband died of AIDS in April, 1996. Her husband had AIDS before marriage but this fact was concealed from Jahnabi. After the death of her husband, she was harassed, discriminated against and thrown out of her in-laws house and was not allowed to take her belongings and her daughter Kasturi with her. She got her belongings back and the custody of her daughter only after the intervention of the court and the police. Back in Nagaon, Jahnabi discovered that her husband had died of AIDS and that she too had been infected. Kasturi, who also had been infected, died in 1998 at the age of two.<ref name="Infochange" /><ref name="FP">Simantik Dowerah [http://www.firstpost.com/living/world-aids-day-we-fight-for-benefits-but-forget-the-issue-145119.html "World Aids Day: 'We fight for benefits but forget the issue'"], ''[[Firstpost]]'', 1 December 2011</ref>
==Work== After the death of her daughter, Goswami moved to [[Guwahati]] and joined the government-run Assam State AIDS Control Society (ASACS). In 2002, Jahnabhi Goswami formed the Assam Network of Positive People (ANPP) with the help of Manipur Network of Positive People. ANPP aimed at building capacity and skills of people living with the virus and creating an enabling environment for them in society which if free from discrimination. ANPP has started a drop-in centre with free counseling and medicinal support to the patient and also provides referral services and free medical check-ups.
Goswami held the position of the President of ANPP and is currently its treasurer. She also held the position of the General Secretary of The Indian Network of Positive People (INP+), the largest Network of people living with HIV/AIDS and is currently the President. She is the first women to be the President of INP+.<ref name="Infochange" /><ref name="FP" />
Goswami has also been involved in the politics of the region. In 2006, Jahnabi Goswami was expected to be the Congress party’s candidate from the Barhampur assembly constituency in eastern Assam's Nagaon district against former Assam chief minister [[Prafulla Kumar Mahanta]]. But later her name was turned down. Jahnabi Goswami continued to campaign for the Congress party. She believes that through her active involvement in the election campaigns, not only can she help spread more awareness about the disease, but also make the people living with HIV/AIDS feel like they are an integral part of the society.<ref name="dna">{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-cong-fields-hiv-positive-woman-against-former-assam-cm-1016187|title=Cong fields HIV-positive woman against former Assam CM - Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=4 March 2006|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="tele">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1090413/jsp/northeast/story_10812222.jsp|title=The Telegraph - Calcutta (Kolkata) - Northeast - HIV crusader hits campaign trail for Congress|website=www.telegraphindia.com}}</ref>
Goswami’s work mainly deals with women and children living with or affected by HIV/AIDS. In 2012, ANPP, jointly with ASACS opened the Kasturi Special Care Home in Guwahati which offers free shelter, food and education to orphans infected and affected with HIV/AIDS .She has also been campaigning to make pre-marital HIV/AIDS tests mandatory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1120804/jsp/northeast/story_15810738.jsp#.VJ171cCQ|title=CM inaugurates home for HIV kids|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2003/06/16/d30616130581.htm|title=The Daily Star Web Edition Vol. 4 Num 19|website=archive.thedailystar.net}}</ref>
The life of Goswami was also featured in a 2008 short documentary, Jahnabi’s World, directed by Debjani Mukherjee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2841564/|title=Jahnabi's World|date=26 November 2017|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}</ref>
Goswami was awarded the IBN7 Zindagi LIVE Awards in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantvinfo.com/1st-edition-of-ibn7-zindagi-live-awards/|title=Indian Television News|website=Indian Television News}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Jean-Charles Boisset<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image =Jean-Charles Boisset - Boisset Collection.jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by the blind and visually impaired's speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1969}}<!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people. Supply only the year unless the exact date is already widely published, as per WP:DOB. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = [[Vougeot]], [[France]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = French | other_names = | occupation = President of the [[Boisset Collection]] | years_active = | spouse = Gina Gallo (2009-) | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Jean-Charles Boisset''' (also known as '''JCB''') is a French [[vintner]] and the proprietor of the [[Boisset Collection]]. Under Boisset's leadership, the Boisset Collection operates 24 wineries in [[California]], [[France]], and [[Canada]].
Boisset comes from a viticultural family. His father and mother founded a winery in Burgundy, France, in 1961. When a young Boisset visited [[Buena Vista Winery]], in California, with his sister and grandparents, the 11 year old Boisset shared with his family that he wanted to live in America one day.
Boisset moved to California in the early nineties and purchased his first winery, Lyeth Estates and in 1999 he co-founded [[Domaine de la Vougeraie]] with his sister, Nathalie. In 2003, Boisset purchased [[DeLoach Vineyards]] in California's [[Russian River Valley AVA]], followed by [[Raymond Vineyards]], located in [[Napa Valley]], California, in 2009 and Buena Vista Winery, located in [[Sonoma, California|Sonoma]], California, in 2011.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/>
==Early life== Jean-Charles Boisset is the son of [[Jean-Claude Boisset|Jean-Claude]] and Claudine Boisset, who founded their family winery, Jean-Claude Boisset, [[Burgundy, France]] in 1961. In 1964, the winery acquired its first vineyard, [[Les Evocelles]] in the [[Gevrey-Chambertin]] commune.<ref name="Lechmere">{{cite web|last1=Lechmere|first1=Adam|title=The Interview: Life is a Cabaret For Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://www.wine-searcher.com/m/2014/02/the-interview--jean-charles-boisset|website=Wine Searcher|accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Julian1">{{cite web|last1=Julia|first1=Christina|title=Personality: Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://www.northbaybiz.com/Bonus_Issues/GameChangers/Personality_Jean_Charles_Boisset.php|website=[[NorthBay biz]]|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> Boisset was born in [[Vougeot]], France in 1969.<ref name="Julian1"/><ref name="JCBFAF1">{{cite web|title=Jean-Charles Boisset|url=https://frenchamerican.org/jean-charles-boisset|website=French-American Foundation|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Kostrzewa">{{cite web|last1=Kostrzewa|first1=Susan|title=Celebrate At Home With Jean-Charles Boisset & Gina Gallo|url=http://www.winemag.com/2010/11/12/celebrate-at-home-with-jean-charles-boisset-gina-gallo/|website=Wine Enthusiast|accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref>
When Boisset was seven years old, he tried two wines from [[Burgundy]]: a 1969 [[Clos de Vougeot]] and a 1964 [[Bonnes Mares]]. He would eventually name a wine under his JCB label "No. 7," as a tribute to the first time he tried wine.<ref name="Lurie"/>
Boisset's grandparents were part of the [[French Resistance]] and his grandfather would go on to fight in [[World War II]]. His grandparents' involvement in the war led to their having a strong admiration for Americans, and as a child, Boisset remembers his grandparents telling him stories about the Americans who helped free France. His grandparents encouraged him to visit America and to dream to live there one day.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/>
At the age of 11, Boisset and his sister Nathalie visited America in 1981 for the first time with his grandparents. They visited [[California]], specifically [[Monterey, California|Monterey]], [[San Francisco]], and [[Sonoma, California|Sonoma]].<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> Their grandparents took them on a tour of [[Buena Vista Winery]] and later that day, Boisset's grandparents let him and his sister try a Buena Vista Winery [[Chardonnay]] that they had purchased during the winery visit.<ref name="Fletcher4">{{cite web|last1=Fletcher|first1=Janet|title=Buena Vista Winery's new owner sees future in past|url=http://www.sfgate.com/wine/article/Buena-Vista-Winery-s-new-owner-sees-future-in-past-5430089.php|website=SFGate|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Stierch1">{{cite web|last1=Stierch|first1=Sarah|title=Revitalizing heritage: Jean-Charles Boisset and Buena Vista|url=http://sonomasun.com/2015/08/31/revitalizing-heritage-jean-charles-boisset-and-buena-vista/|website=Sonoma Valley Sun|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> Regarding that wine, Boisset said "I was transfixed - such pure, elegant, and tropical notes that we did not know in [[Burgundy]]!" After their visit to the winery, Boisset suggested to his sister that he hoped to one day own a winery in California. In 2011, he would purchase Buena Vista.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/>
As a young man, Boisset was less interested in wine than other pursuits. He almost became a professional [[footballer]].<ref name="Blanning"/> He studied business and finance at the [[University of London]], followed by graduate studies at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]].<ref name="GR1">{{cite web|title=Go West Young Man – with Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://www.graperadio.com/archives/2013/06/07/go-west-young-man-with-jean-charles-boisset/|website=Grape Radio|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="BacchusBeery">{{cite web|title=Jean-Charles Boisset – Powerful Combination of Old World Sensibilities and New World Zeal|url=http://wine-blog.bacchusandbeery.com/wine-blog/winemaker-interview/jean-charles-boisset-powerful-combination-old-world-sensibilities-new-world-zeal/|website=Bacchus & Beery Wine Blog|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref> He earned a [[Masters of Business Administration]] from the [[University of San Francisco]].<ref name="Mansson">{{cite web|last1=Mansson|first1=Per-Henrik|title=France's New Faces|url=http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/Frances-New-Faces_1812|website=Wine Spectator|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
==Life in wine==
{{main article|Boisset Collection}}
Boisset was exposed to the wine industry at an early age. He was raised in his family's home near [[Clos de Vougeot]] and spent considerable time in the family's vineyards. In the early nineties, the Boisset family sought to close the office of Boisset America (now called the Boisset Collection) in San Francisco. Boisset chose to operate the office, relocating to San Francisco. Shortly thereafter, Boisset purchased his first California winery, [[Lyeth Estates]].<ref name="Blanning"/> In 1999, Boisset and his sister, Nathalie Boisset, created [[Domaine de la Vougeraie]] from the family's estate in [[Côte de Nuits]] and [[Côte de Beaune]].<ref name="Vino1">{{cite web|title=Domaine de la Vougeraie, Premeaux-Prissey, France: Some Current Releases|url=http://www.vinography.com/archives/2010/12/domaine_de_la_vougeraie_nuits-.html|website=Vinography|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBR">{{cite web|title=Domaine de la Vougeraie|url=http://www.bbr.com/producer-1020-domaine-de-la-vougeraie|website=Berry, Bros. & Rudd|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> In 2003, Boisset purchased [[DeLoach Vineyards]] in California's [[Russian River Valley AVA]], followed by [[Raymond Vineyards]], located in [[Napa Valley]], California, in 2009 and Buena Vista Winery, located in [[Sonoma, California|Sonoma]], California, in 2011.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/>
In total, the Boisset Collection includes 24 wineries in [[Burgundy]], [[Beaujolais]], the [[Rhône Valley]], the [[South of France]], Napa, Sonoma and [[Monterey]], California, and [[Quebec]]. The family's estates are [[biodynamic agriculture|certified biodynamic]] and/or organic wine.<ref name="Lechmere"/><ref name="GR1"/>
Boisset is interested in small production wines that are made utilizing Burgundian winemaking techniques, including the use of [[pigeage]], open-top [[fermentation]], and [[terroir]].<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> His business style has been described as being a "more consumer-driven, [[New World]] approach."<ref name="Blanning">{{cite web|last1=Blanning|first1=Beverly|title=Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://www.burgundytoday.com/gourmet-traveller/jean-charles-boisset.htm|website=Burgundy Today|publisher=Decanter|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> As a wine drinker, Boisset has cited [[Pinot Noir]] as his favorite varietal and on his [[wikt:deathbed|death bed]] he would drink a 2006 and a 2003 Clos du Vougeot Blanc.<ref name="Lurie"/><ref name="Blanning"/>
===Lyeth Estates===
Lyeth Estates was the first American winery purchased by Boisset.<ref name="Blanning"/>
===Domaine de la Vougeraie===
{{main article|Domaine de la Vougeraie}}
Boisset and his sister Nathalie founded [[Domaine de la Vougeraie]] in 1999, consolidating their family's vineyards in Burgundy.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/><ref name="Lurie">{{cite web|last1=Lurie|first1=Joshua|title=Interview: Jean-Charles Boisset (Domaine de la Vougeraie)|url=http://foodgps.com/qa-with-jean-charles-boisset/|website=Food GPS|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> This consolidation included vineyards in the [[Clos de Vougeot]]. They also focused on maintaining, or introducing, sustainable farming to each vineyard.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> The same year as the founding of Domaine de la Vougeraie, Boisset made his first wine, working with 14 other people to process the grapes by hand. He produced two wines: a Clos du Vougeot Blanc and La Montée Rouge.<ref name="Lurie"/>
===DeLoach Vineyards===
{{main article|DeLoach Vineyards}}
Located in the Russian River Valley AVA, DeLoach Vineyards was founded in 1975.<ref name="OlkenFurstenthal2010">{{cite book|author1=Charles E. Olken|author2=Joseph Furstenthal|title=The New Connoisseurs' Guidebook to California Wine and Wineries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n5b_qpeCvG8C&pg=PA113|year=2010|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-25313-1|page=113}}</ref> Boisset acquired DeLoach Vineyards in 2003. DeLoach produces [[Chardonnay]], [[Pinot Noir]] and [[Zinfandel]] in the [[Russian River Valley AVA]] in [[Sonoma County]].<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> The purchase has been described as a "tribute," to Burgundy.<ref name="Julian1"/> Boisset has described the Russian River Valley as "the next [[Burgundy wine|Côte d'Or]]."<ref name="Blanning"/> Brian Maloney serves as Director of Winemaking at DeLoach Vineyards.<ref name="Joe">{{cite web|title=Winemaker Brian Maloney zips and dashes between DeLoach and Buena Vista wineries|url=http://www.winecountrygetaways.com/winemaker-zips-and-dashes-between-deloach-and-buena-vista-wineries/|website=Wine Country Getaways|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
===Raymond Vineyards===
In 2009,<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> Boisset purchased [[Raymond Vineyards]]. The winery was founded in 1971 by Roy Raymond, Sr. and his two sons, Walter and Roy. Raymond's first vintage was in 1974.<ref name="Franson1">{{cite web|last1=Franson|first1=Paul|title=Jean-Charles Boisset is bringing new energy to a venerable St. Helena winery|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/lifestyles/food-and-cooking/wine/jean-charles-boisset-is-bringing-new-energy-to-a-venerable/article_0add9f7a-b1a7-11df-a480-001cc4c03286.html|website=Napa Valley Register|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> In 1989, [[Kirin Company|Kirin Holdings]] purchased the winery, with the Raymond family still managing the property and production.<ref name="Berger">{{cite web|last1=Berger|first1=Dan|title=Wine Family Has Stake With Japanese Owners|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-10/business/fi-1734_1_kirin-napa-valley-stock-and-barrels|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Boisset purchased the property from Kirin. [[Stephanie Putnam]] was hired as Director of Winemaker in 2010. Putnam collaborates with Consulting Winemaker Philippe Melka to produce Raymond Vineyards wines.<ref name="WCG1">{{cite web|title=Stephanie Putnam named Raymond Vineyards Director of Winemaking|url=http://www.winebusiness.com/people/?go=getPeopleArticle&dataId=74608|website=Wine Business|publisher=Wine Communications Group|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
Under Boisset's leadership, Raymond became a biodynamic producer.<ref name="Franson1"/> On-site is a 2-acre exhibition about biodynamic farming, called the Theater of Nature. The self-guided exhibit is the largest exhibit showcasing biodynamic practices in the region. It aims to teach guests about how biodynamic farming impacts Raymond Vineyards' wines via a five act theater-inspired exhibition.<ref name="Yadegaran">{{cite web|last1=Yadegaran|first1=Jessica|title=Winery Adventure: Raymond Vineyards, Napa|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/libations/ci_25036031/winery-adventure-raymond-vineyards-napa|website=Drink|publisher=The Mercury News|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> The Theater of Nature's gardens produce biodynamic and organic produce.<ref name="Franson1"/><ref name="Sweet">{{cite web|last1=Sweet|first1=Carey|title=Raymond Vineyards a feast of the senses|url=http://www.sfgate.com/travel/tastingroom/article/Raymond-Vineyards-a-feast-of-the-senses-5060702.php|website=SFGate|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> The winery is also operated on 100% [[solar power]].<ref name="NVRsolar">{{cite web|title=Boisset wineries go 100 percent solar|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/lifestyles/food-and-cooking/wine/boisset-wineries-go-percent-solar/article_1013f486-b8d3-11e2-934e-0019bb2963f4.html|website=Napa Valley Register|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
Additionally, Raymond is known for the many "experiences," offered to guests, including the "Crystal Cellar," which features [[mannequins]] hanging from the ceiling, [[Baccarat]] crystal and silver made by [[Christofle]]. The "red room," has a [[burlesque]]-style decor, with red velvet. The winery also has a dog friendly space named after Boisset's own dog, Frenchie.<ref name="Sprauve1">{{cite web|last1=Sprauve|first1=Angella|title=A Sparkling Imagination: Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://hauteliving.com/2014/01/sparkling-imagination-jean-charles-boisset/444657/|website=Haute Living|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
In 2012, Raymond Vineyards earned ''[[Wine Enthusiast]]'' "American Winery of the Year" award.<ref name="BoonieRV2012">{{cite web|last1=Boonie|first1=Virginie|title=2012 American Winery of the Year: Raymond Vineyards|url=http://www.winemag.com/2012/11/15/2012-american-winery-of-the-year-raymond-vineyards/|website=News & Trends|publisher=Wine Enthusiast|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> In 2014, the winery was named by Great Wine Capitals as the Regional Winner for "Innovative Wine Tourism Experiences."<ref name="GWC2014">{{cite web|title=Raymond Vineyards|url=http://www.greatwinecapitals.com/best-of/san-francisco-napa-valley/raymond-vineyards|website=Best of Wine Tourism|publisher=Great Wine Capitals|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Raymond Vineyards was named "Best Unique Tasting Experience" by [[CellarPass]] in 2014.<ref name="CP2014Award">{{cite web|title=CellarPass Announces 2014 Destination Awards Winners|url=http://about.cellarpass.com/portfolio/2014-cellarpass-destination-awards-winners/|publisher=CellarPass|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> The ''[[North Bay Bohemian]]'' named Raymond Vineyards the "Best Winetasting Room" in Napa Valley in 2015 and 2016 and for having the best [[Cabernet Sauvignon]].<ref name="NBB2016Bes">{{cite web|title=Readers Picks: 2016|url=http://www.bohemian.com/northbay/readers-picks-dining/BestOf?oid=2945463|website=Best of 2016|publisher=North Bay Bohemian|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="NBBBest15">{{cite web|title=Readers Picks: Food & Drink|url=http://www.bohemian.com/northbay/readers-picks-food-and-drink/BestOf?oid=2703918|website=Best of 2015|publisher=North Bay Bohemian|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
====Collaboration with John Legend====
In late 2015, Raymond introduced [[LVE: Legend Vineyard Exclusive]], a label featuring a Napa Valley [[Chardonnay]] and a Napa Valley [[Cabernet Sauvignon]] created by Boisset, Stephanie Putnam, and singer-songwriter [[John Legend]]. In 2015, Legend performed at [[Auction Napa Valley]], performing as part of Raymond Vineyards' [[auction]] lot, which helped to raise $850,000 for Napa Valley charities. The lot included six double magnums of LVE, dinner, and a private concert by Legend at Boisset's Napa Valley home.<ref name="Honeycutt">{{cite news|last1=Honeycutt|first1=Mira Advani|title=9 highlights from the Auction Napa Valley 2015|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/RVD-LE-PAN-9-Highlights-Auction-Napa-Valley-.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Le Pan|date=12 June 2015}}</ref> In 2016, the collaboration between Raymond Vineyards and Legend was awarded the inaugural "Wine & Culture" award by ''Wine Enthusiast''.<ref name="Newman">{{cite web|last1=Newman|first1=Kara|title=A Magical, Musical Wine Star Awards|url=http://www.winemag.com/gallery/a-magical-musical-evening-for-wine-enthusiasts-2015-wine-star-awards/|website=Wine Enthusiast|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
===Buena Vista Winery===
{{main article|Buena Vista Winery}}
Boisset purchased Buena Vista Winery, the oldest commercial winery in California, in 2011.<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> It was the first American winery that Boisset had visited, when he was 11 years old. Upon purchasing Buena Vista, Boisset launched a major renovation of the property, which had suffered from disrepair. The historic champagne cellars, built in 1864, almost collapsed and needed to be repaired. Boisset hired contractors, including [[historic preservation|preservationists]] to assist with the renovations. The renovations completed, the winery began producing wine in the original cellars for the first time in 2015.<ref name="Stierch1"/> Additionally, the winery has a wine tool museum and houses a "Bubble Lounge," where guests can taste and purchase Boisset's JCB sparkling wine.<ref name="Sprauve1"/><ref name="Dinkelspiel">{{cite web|last1=Dinkelspiel|first1=Frances|title=It’s one long party at Sonoma’s Buena Vista Winery|url=http://www.berkeleyside.com/2015/03/23/its-one-long-party-at-sonomas-buena-vista-winery/|website=NOSH|publisher=Berkeleyside|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
===JCB by Jean-Charles Boisset===
Boisset has his own wine label, JCB. Each wine in the portfolio is named after a number, i.e. No. 3 JCB, similar to [[Chanel No. 5]].<ref name="Lechmere"/> JCB No. 39 is named after the year Boisset's grandparents were married.<ref name="Sweeney1">{{cite news|last1=Sweeney|first1=Kate|title=Your peek inside San Francisco's swankiest new lounge|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/JCB-Forbes-Travel-Guide-Your-Peek-Inside-SF-Swankiest-New-Lounge-01.05.2015.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Forbes Travel Guide}}</ref> The label produces still and [[sparkling wine]] from France, mainly Burgundy and [[Provence]], California, specifically Napa and Sonoma.<ref name="Franson">{{cite news|last1=Franson|first1=Paul|title=JCB tasting salon and Atelier|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/JCB-NapaLife-JCB-Tasting-Salon-and-Atelier-09.29.2016.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=NapaLife|issue=9|date=29 February 2016}}</ref>
====JCB Tasting Lounge====
A tasting lounge for JCB wines is located at DeLoach Winery, Raymond Vineyards and Buena Vista Winery.<ref name="Stierch1"/> In 2015, JCB opened the JCB by Jean-Charles Boisset Tasting Lounge at the [[The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company|Ritz-Carlton San Francisco]]. Located in a room adjacent to the [[concierge]] desk, the lounge has a capacity of 10 guests and serves wine flights and food and wine pairings from the hotel's Parallel 37 restaurant.<ref name="Mobley">{{cite web|last1=Mobley|first1=Esther|title=Jean-Charles Boisset opens opulent tasting lounge at the Ritz-Carlton|url=http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2015/09/10/jean-charles-boisset-opens-opulent-tasting-lounge-at-the-ritz-carlton/|website=Inside Scoop SF|publisher=SFGate|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> The lounge offers JCB wines and additional wines from Buena Vista and Domaine de la Vougeraie. The space has been described as an "opulent French parlor," and "over the top," due to the decor, which includes purple [[velvet]] couches, gold fringe stools, and leopard print carpet.<ref name="Sweeney1"/> Additionally, the lounge sells [[Goyard]] handbags, Baccarat products, and Boisset's collection of unisex [[brooch]]es.<ref name="Mobley"/>
====Tasting Salon and Atelier by JCB==== In 2016, Boisset opened the JCB Tasting Salon and Atelier by JCB in [[Yountville]].<ref name="Carter1"/> Like the San Francisco-based lounge, wines are available in three different flights, with bottles available for take away purchase.<ref name="Franson"/><ref name="Carter2">{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Kelly E.|title=Jean-Charles Boisset Brings His Inimitable Style to Yountville|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/JCB-Haute-Living-JC-Brings-His-Inimitable-Style-to-Yountville-03.26.2016.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Haute Living|date=26 February 2016}}</ref> The lounge has a digital touch table designed by [[Ideum]], that guides guests through wine tastings and builds a wine profile based on guests preferred wines.<ref name="Penn1">{{cite news|last1=Penn|first1=Cyril|title=The coolest new destination in Napa Valley is in Yountville|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/JCB-WBM-Blog-Cyril-Penn-Coolest-Destination-is-Yountville-02.01.2016.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Wine Business|date=1 March 2016}}</ref> The lounge is decorated with [[leopard print]] couches, and [[cheetah]] print stools.<ref name="Franson"/><ref name="Carter2"/> Mirrors framed in gold hang from the ceiling, along with Baccarat [[chandeliers]].<ref name="Carter2"/> It sells [[luxury good]]s, including Baccarat crystal, Christofle silver, and [[Bernardaud]] [[porcelain]]. Additionally, it sells high end [[art book]]s.<ref name="Carter2"/> The Atelier sells high end foods, including rare cheeses, meats, [[foie gras]], [[smoked salmon]] and [[caviar]].<ref name="Franson"/><ref name="Carter2"/><ref name="Fletcher">{{cite news|last1=Fletcher|first1=Janet|title=Premier cheese shops in Napa Valley|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/JCB-SF-Gate-Premier-Cheese-Shops-of-NV-02.25.2016.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=SFGate|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=25 February 2016}}</ref> The Atelier is decorated with a Baccarat chandelier and [[gold leaf]] covered shelves.<ref name="Fletcher"/> It was named the 2nd best place to shop in Napa Valley by ''[[USA Today]]'' and a cross between "[[Fifth Avenue]] and [[Champs-Elysees]]".<ref name="Penn1"/><ref name="Rebmann1">{{cite news|last1=Rebmann|first1=Deb|title=10 best shopping stops in Napa Valley Wine Country|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/JCB-USA-Today-10-Best-Shopping-in-NV-Wine-Country-02.24.2015.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=USA Today|date=24 February 2016}}</ref>
====Surrealist====
Under the JCB label, Boisset also produces The Surrealist, a Napa Valley red blend wine, decanters, and jewelry in one package. A piece of jewelry is used on the bottle in lieu of a traditional wine label, reflecting old world wine necklaces, and a Baccarat crystal stopper transforms the bottle into a decanter.<ref name="Julian1"/> A set, which includes a bottle of wine, the wine decanter and a brooch costs $500. The bottle can be reused as a decanter after it is emptied. The wine is a blend of [[Petit Verdot]] and Cabernet Sauvignon from eastern Napa Valley and [[St. Helena]].<ref name="Carter3">{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Kelly E.|title=A surreal wine bottle you won't want to recycle|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/JCB-Haute-Living-A-Surreal-Wine-Bottle-You-Wont-Want-to-Recycle-03.25.2015.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Haute Living|date=25 March 2015}}</ref>
===Alternative wine packaging===
Boisset has acknowledged that while glass wine bottles have "romance and aesthetic," and the importance of glass for aging wine. However, he believes that alternative packaging "helps to improve value, ecology and convenience." Boisset is interested in packaging that reduces [[carbon footprint]]s while still providing a quality wine experience, especially in places where glass bottles are not allowed.<ref name="Cervin">{{cite web|last1=Cervin|first1=Michael|title=Q&A with Jean-Charles Boisset, of Boisset Family Estates|url=http://www.intowine.com/qa-jean-charles-boisset-boisset-family-estates|website=Intowine|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
As the president of Boisset Collection, he is credited with the creation of [[French Rabbit]], a wine brand that uses [[Tetrapak]]s instead of wine bottles.<ref name="Lechmere"/> The brand sells approximately 150,000 cases a year in the United States and Canada.<ref name="Lechmere"/> He also introduced [[Yellow Jersey (wine)|Yellow Jersey]], a wine brand sold in [[plastic]] bottles, using wine from [[Vin de Pays d'Oc]].<ref name="Blanning"/> In 2011, Boisset introduced "barrel-to-barrel," packaging at Raymond Vineyards and DeLoach. Similar to a [[boxed wine]] concept, 10- to 3-liter bags filled with wine can be placed in reusable barrels for restaurant/bar or home use. The empty bags weigh 99% lighter than a case of empty wine bottles, thus more affordable to ship, and the wine lasts longer.<ref name="Locke">{{cite web|last1=Locke|first1=Michelle|title=Roll out the barrel to keep wine fresh|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/mar/31/roll-out-the-barrel-to-keep-wine-fresh/|website=Culture|publisher=Washington Times|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
Boisset has also introduced a [[Beaujolais]] in an [[aluminum]] container called [[Mommessin]]. The wine is meant to be drunk chilled and the bottle turns blue when it is at the right drinking temperature. It takes 10 minutes to chill, versus 30 minutes in a glass bottle.<ref name="Hulkower">{{cite web|last1=Hulkower|first1=Bonnie|title=The French Rabbit Strike Again- TH Interviews Jean Charles Boisset about the wine industry|url=http://www.treehugger.com/green-food/the-french-rabbit-strike-again-th-interviews-jean-charles-boisset-about-the-wine-industry.html|website=Treehugger|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> He is also credited with being one of the first Burgundian [[vintner]]s to use screwcaps instead of [[wine cork|corks]].<ref name="Lechmere2">{{cite web|last1=Lechmere|first1=Adam|title=Jean-Charles Boisset and Gina Gallo marry|url=http://www.decanter.com/wine-news/jean-charles-boisset-and-gina-gallo-marry-65004/|website=Wine News|publisher=Decanter|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Boisset met [[Gina Gallo]], winemaker at [[Gallo Family Vineyards]], in 2006<ref name="Merchant1">{{cite web|last1=Merchant|first1=Kathy|title=Wine "Rock Stars" Headline International Wine Festival|url=https://vinoventurescincinnati.com/tag/boisset-collection/|website=Vino Ventures|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> at a [[tasting room]] in [[Bordeaux]]. They were married in 2009 at the [[Fairmont San Francisco]].<ref name="Joie1">{{cite web|title=True Joie de Vivre|url=http://www.sonomamag.com/true-joie-de-vivre/|website=Sonoma Magazine}}</ref> The couple have twin girls, born in 2011.<ref name="Isle1">{{cite web|last1=Isle|first1=Ray|title=A Dinner Party with Gina Gallo and Jean-Charles Boisset|url=http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/a-dinner-party-from-gina-gallo-and-jean-charles-boisset|website=Food & Wine|publisher=Time, Inc.|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
In 2011, Boisset and Gallo purchased the former home of [[Robert Mondavi]] in [[Napa Valley]].<ref name="Rauber">{{cite web|last1=Rauber|first1=Chris|title=Secret is out: Jean-Charles Boisset and Gina Gallo bought Robert Mondavi estate|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2011/12/secret-is-out-jean-charles-boisset.html|website=Bay Area Biztalk|publisher=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> The family also has an apartment in the [[Nob Hill]] neighborhood of San Francisco and a home in [[Burgundy]] in [[France]].<ref name="Kostrzewa"/><ref name="Joie1"/> The family travels to Burgundy several times a year, to spend time with Boisset's family and so their daughters can learn about the French culture.<ref name="Joie1"/>
Despite both of their roles in the wine industry, Boisset and Gallo do not officially collaborate on wine projects.<ref name="Lechmere2"/>
==Achievements==
Since 2007, Boisset has been named to ''[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter]]''s Power List. In 2008, he was named "Innovator of the Year" by ''[[Wine Enthusiast]]''. In 2013, he was named one of the "20 most admired people in the North American wine industry," by ''[[Vineyard & Winery Management]]''.<ref name="VWM13">{{cite news|title=The 20 most admired people in the North American wine industry|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/BFE-Vineyard-Winery-Management-20-Most-Admired-Nov-2013.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Vineyard & Winery Management|date=November 2013}}</ref> That same year, Boisset was awarded the first ever recipient of the French-American Partnership of Excellence Award awarded by the [[French-American Foundation]].<ref name="JCBFAF1"/> In 2014, Boisset and Gallo were awarded the "Global Entrepreneurship Award" by [[John F. Kennedy University]].<ref name="GRBCCB">{{cite web|last1=Gram-Reefer|first1=Bill|title=Entrepreneurship awards celebrate innovation and leadership|url=https://contracostabee.com/entrepreneurship-awards-iel-jfk-university/|website=Business|publisher=Contra Costa Bee|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> That same year, he was the 2014 Jefferson Award Honoree from the [[Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts]].<ref name="PAFA16">{{cite web|title=2014 Jefferson Award Honoree|url=https://www.pafa.org/2014-jefferson-award-honoree|website=Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> The following year, in 2015, Boisset was named an Honorary Chair of [[Sonoma Valley Wine Country Weekend]].<ref name="Stierch1"/> In 2015 and 2016, he was named to ''[[Haute Living]]'''s San Francisco's Haute 100 list.<ref name="Carter1">{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Kelly E.|title=San Francisco's Haute 100 2016|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/BFE-Haute-Living-SF-Haute-100-List-03.11.2016.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Haute Living|date=11 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="100Haute2015">{{cite news|title=The Haute 100 Issue|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/BFE-Haute-Living-Haute-100-02.01.2015.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Haute Living|date=January 2015}}</ref>
==Style==
Boisset's fashion sense has been described as "theatrical," "unpredictable," "flamboyant" and "fantastical."<ref name="Sprauve1"/><ref name="Carter1"/> He wears designer suits and jackets by [[Tom Ford]], [[Gucci]], and [[Lanvin (company)|Lanvin]]. Additionally, he is an enthusiast of [[Louboutin]] shoes.<ref name="Sprauve1"/> His red [[sock]]s have been described as his "trademark." He was voted "best dressed," in a 2014 reader's poll by the ''[[Nob Hill Gazette]]''.<ref name="NHGBest14">{{cite news|title=Best Dressed 2014|url=http://www.jcbwines.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/JCBGazetteBestDressedJuly14.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2016|work=Nob Hill Gazette|date=2014}}</ref>

[[File:Nathan of Gaza.jpg|thumb|200px|Portrait of Nathan of Gaza, from 1906 Jewish Encyclopedia.]] '''Nathan Benjamin ben Elisha Hayyim ha'Levi Ashkenazi / Ghazzati''' or '''Nathan of Gaza''' ({{lang-he|נתן העזתי}}{{lrm}}; 1643–1680) was a theologian and author born in [[Jerusalem]]. After his marriage in 1663 he moved to [[Gaza City|Gaza]], where he became famous as a prophet for the alleged messiah, [[Sabbatai Zevi]]. ==Biography== Although he is referred to by names such as Abraham Nathan ben Elisha Hayyim Ashkenazi or Rabbi Nathan Ashkenazi of Gaza, he is more commonly known as Nathan of Gaza. After studying [[Talmud]] and [[Kabbalah]] in his native town under [[Jacob Hagiz]], he settled at Gaza, whence his name "Ghazzati". The fact of his father being a German Jew gave him the name of "[[Ashkenazi]]". As brilliant as he was as a kabbalistic theologian and as a student, Nathan of Gaza was also endowed with other remarkable characteristics that ultimately helped to promote the messianic claims surrounding Shabbetai Zevi. He was known, for example, for his prophetic visions as well as for his ideological and radical views, all of which helped to shape the eventual mystical movement around Shabbethai Zevi. His visionary capabilities in particular not only constructed the foundations for Sabbateanism, but they also aided him in discovering the group’s historical figure, Shabbetai Zevi. Nathan of Gaza was born in Jerusalem around 1643-1644; he died on Friday, January 11, 1680 in Macedonia. Although he grew up in Jerusalem, his parents were not born in Ottoman Syria. On the contrary, they had immigrated from Poland or Germany. His father, Elisha Hayyim ben Jacob, was a distinguished rabbinic intellectual who served as an envoy of Jerusalem collecting donations for impoverished Jews. During his travels, he would distribute kabbalistic works, which he had obtained in Jerusalem. Upon settling in Ottoman Palestine, Elisha Hayyim ben Jacob took on the surname "Ashkenazi" as a means of differentiating his family and himself from the largely Sephardic inhabitants of the Ottoman province. He died in Morocco in 1673. Prior to his father’s death, Nathan of Gaza began studying under [[Jacob Hagiz]]. The relationship between these two religious devotees would continue for many years. In fact, Nathan of Gaza would spend a majority of his life – up until about 1664 – with his teacher at a rabbinic college. During this academic period, documents were written that described his interest in and persistence towards academic work. It is said that he was “…an extremely gifted student, of quick apprehension and a brilliant intellect. His talents…[were] noteworthy for their rare combination of intellectual power and capacity for profound thinking with imagination and strong emotional sensitivity…”Gershom Scholem, ''Sabbatai Sevi: The Mystical Messiah'' (Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1973), 201. In and of itself, Nathan of Gaza was an extremely gifted pupil. His intellectual brilliance and his intense focus on his studies, however, did not limit or prevent him – as occurs with most intensely devoted religious individuals –from experiencing many of the Jewish rites of passage. In fact, at the age of nineteen or twenty, he married the daughter of an affluent Jew named Samuel Lissabona. The nuptials were believed to have taken place before the end of the year 1663, when he joined his wife’s family in Gaza. There, he was able to focus considerably on his religious studies. It is upon moving to the area of Gaza that Nathan of Gaza began to take up a more in-depth study of Kabbalah. Only upon delving into the mysterious realm of Jewish mysticism did he begin to embark on mystical experiences. An example of such a transformative incident can be seen with his prophetic awakening, which he describes in a letter written in 1673:
''When I had attained the age of twenty, I began to study the book Zohar and some of the Lurianic writings. [According to the Talmud] he who wants to purify himself receives the aid of Heaven; and thus He sent me some of His holy angels and blessed spirits who revealed to me many of the mysteries of the Torah. In that same year, my force having been stimulated by the visions of the angels and the blessed souls, I was undergoing a prolonged fast in the week before the feast of Purim. Having locked myself in a separate room in holiness and purity…the spirit came over me, my hair stood on end and my knees shook and I beheld the merkabah, and I saw visions of God all day long and all night…''Gershom Scholem, ''Sabbatai Sevi: The Mystical Messiah'', 204.
This vision lasted approximately twenty-four hours and was said to have had a powerful impact on his overall perception of reality as well as his entire self. While the revelation was overpowering and transformative, it was the only visual moment where Nathan of Gaza felt that he was a true prophet. Nevertheless, in addition to his physical and mental alteration, there was another important component to the vision: Nathan of Gaza believed that a man by the name of Shabbetai Zevi was the messiah. This strong belief in Shabbetai Zevi as the next leader of the Jewish people marked the initiation of the first Sabbatean believer, Nathan of Gaza. It also constituted the beginning of the Sabbatean movement itself. Nathan of Gaza’s prophecy about Shabbetai Zevi was not his only mental visualization. On the contrary, as the years passed, he would have many other visions, all of which would aid his movement and promote the belief in Shabbetai Zevi. His second vision in fact came on the evening of the Shavu’ot festival in the spring of 1665. Unlike his prophetic awakening, here, Nathan of Gaza was said to have undergone a spiritual possession by a maggid, or a divine spirit. At the moment of this spiritual takeover, he was described as dancing wildly and emitting a special kind of odor. This smell is described in the Zohar and is believed to be associated with the scent of the Garden of Eden as well as of the prophet Elisha and [[Rabbi Isaac Luria]]. While the vision itself is significantly different from that of the prophetic awakening, it does contain several similarities. One of the parallels is that of transformation. Like the prophetic awakening, as soon as the maggidic possession ended, Nathan of Gaza underwent a kind of alteration. Unlike the first vision, this change was not physical or mental. On the contrary, it was one that involved the perception of Nathan of Gaza by the Jewish community. He became viewed by others as a prophet and as a spiritual "doctor". The public’s acknowledgement of Nathan of Gaza as a mystic and as a seer in particular allowed there to be later on an immediate acceptance of Shabbetai Zevi as the next messiah. In general, it is the use of prophecies that plays a central role in this particular movement. In fact, the numerous predictions made by Nathan of Gaza and even Shabbetai Zevi himself caused a significant part of the contemporary Jewish community to become Sabbatean followers. As previously mentioned, Nathan of Gaza envisioned Shabbetai Zevi as the next messiah for the Jewish people. However, Shabbetai Zevi’s acceptance of this messianic role was not instantaneous. In fact, his first encounter with Nathan of Gaza was not about his position as the next Jewish savior, but rather as a "patient" to a "doctor". At the time, Nathan of Gaza was becoming well known as a spiritual physician. Shabbetai Zevi visited him in hopes of “curing” him from an illness that he had contracted. It turns out, of course, that Shabbetai Zevi suffered from a psychological condition which Gershom Scholem identified as manic-depressive psychosis, today normally called "bipolar syndrome". Instead of trying to aid him with his psychological sickness, Nathan of Gaza divulged to Shabbetai Zevi his prophetic vision. Initially, when “…Nathan addressed him as the messiah, ‘he laughed at him and said, ‘I had it [the messianic vocation], but have sent it away.’’” It was only through intense discussion and much persuasion that he was able to sway Shabbetai Zevi into accepting his messianic mission. Then, in May 1665, Shabbetai Zevi made the decision that would place Nathan of Gaza and himself in the public sphere forever. He exposed himself to the world as the true savior. In December 1665, Shabbetai Zevi and Nathan of Gaza parted ways. Shabbetai Zevi embarked on a journey to Turkey where he would begin to advocate his newfound position as the Jewish savior. They would not see each other again until after Shabbetai Zevi's later conversion to Islam. Thus, from the fall of 1665 until the summer of 1666, the two worked arduously on the next stage of their movement: convincing the world that Shabbetai Zevi was the messiah. Seeing that the rabbis of Jerusalem were very hostile to the Shabbethaian movement, Ghazzati proclaimed Gaza to be henceforth the holy city. He first spread about the Messiah's fame by sending circulars from [[Land of Israel|Palestine]] to the most important communities in [[Europe]]. Then he visited several of the chief cities in Europe, [[Africa]], and [[India]], and finally returned to Palestine. Even after Shabbethai Ẓebi's apostasy Ghazzati did not desert his cause; but, thinking it unsafe to remain in Palestine any longer, he made preparations to go to [[Smyrna]]. The rabbis, seeing that the credulous were confirmed anew in their belief, excommunicated all the Shabbethaians, and particularly Ghazzati (Dec 9, 1666), warning everybody against harboring or even approaching him. After a stay of a few months at Smyrna he went (end of April, 1667) to [[Adrianople]], where, in spite of his written promise that he would remain quiet, he continued his agitation. He urged the Shabbethaians of Adrianople to proclaim their adhesion to the cause by abolishing the fasts of the [[17th of Tammuz]] and the [[9th of Ab]]. ==Travels through Europe== Again excommunicated at Adrianople, he went with a few followers to [[Thessaloniki]]. There he met with scant welcome, but had more success in the communities of [[Chios]] and [[Corfu]]. From Corfu he went to [[Venice]] (March, 1668), where the rabbinate and the council of the city compelled him to give them a written confession that all his prophecies were the production of his imagination. The confession was published, whereupon [[Abraham ha-Yakini]], the originator of the Shabbethaian movement, wrote Ghazzati a letter in which he condoled with him over his persecution and expressed his indignation at the acts of the Venetian rabbinate. The Venetian Jews then induced Ghazzati to set out for [[Livorno]], where the Jewish population was known to be inimical to him. They sent an escort with him, ostensibly as a mark of honor, but in reality to prevent him from going elsewhere. He divined their motives in sending him to Livorno, however, and, succeeding in eluding his escort, proceeded to [[Rome]]. In spite of his disguise he was recognized there, and was banished from the city. He then went to Livorno voluntarily, and even there made converts to his cause. From Livorno he returned to Adrianople, and seems to have spent the remainder of his days in travel. ==Works== One of the ways in which Nathan of Gaza was able to persuade the Jewish community about Shabbetai Zevi and Sabbateanism was through his writings. He composed a variety of letters and other written documents that promoted an entirely new kind of theology, one that merged the current notions of Kabbalah (of the time) with elements of Lurianic mysticism, a subject that he studied when he was younger. In addition to creating a “new type” of mysticism, he also composed a document entitled ''Derush ha-Tanninim'' (“Treatise on Dragons”; published by Scholem in ''be-Iqvot Mashiah'' [Jerusalem, 1944]). This article stressed the notion of a “New Law” in which the old positive and negative commandments of the Torah were eliminated. This became the basis for what Gershom Scholem later referred to as “Sabbatean antinomianism.” Not only did Nathan of Gaza publish documents that advocated for a change and a removal of the Jewish laws and commandments, but he also composed a variety of other texts that discussed concepts entirely different from these unorthodoxies. For example, he wrote ''Hadrat Kodesh'' (Constantinople, 1735), a Kabbalistic commentary on the Book of Genesis, particularly on the aspect of creation. Several years later, Nathan of Gaza published ''Ozar Nehmad'' (Venice, 1738), a supplement to the ''Hadrat Kodesh''. In addition to these contributions, he was mistakenly believed to be the author of the ''Hemdat Yamim'', a guidebook for the performance of ritual practices as well as prayers. As evident from these alternative spiritual manuscripts, Nathan of Gaza was not solely a devout Sabbatean follower and believer; he was one who strived to provide an alternative perspective and understanding to the Jewish faith. He also wrote ''Peri 'EtzHadar,'' prayers for the 15th of [[Shebat]] (ib. 1753), and ''Tiqqun Qeri'ah,'' an ascetic work according to Shabbethaian doctrines (Amsterdam, 1666). His account of his travels was translated into German by M. Horschetzky and published in ''Orient, Lit.'' ix. 170-172, 299-301. Overall, the documents that Nathan of Gaza produced and presented were both positively and negatively received by the Jewish community. Some of the rabbis in Jerusalem, for example, were divided over the ideas that Nathan of Gaza wrote. A number of them felt that these written records were sacrilegious; they defied the basic tenets of the Jewish faith. Nevertheless, the composition of these texts provided for a further platform in which Shabbetai Zevi and Nathan of Gaza could promote their Sabbatean ideologies. ==Death== On Friday, January 11, 1680 in Üsküp, [[Ottoman Empire]] (now [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]]), Nathan of Gaza died.[https://books.google.com/books?id=YEnq2cYMTwYC&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q&f=false Sephardi and Middle Eastern Jewries: history and culture in the modern era By Harvey E. Goldberg, Jewish Theological Seminary of America p. 75][https://books.google.com/books?id=NoPZu79hqaEC&pg=PA980 Encyclopedia of the Jewish diaspora: origins, experiences, and culture, Volume 1 p. 980][books.google.com/books?id=kNmGJHrAC3IC&pg=PA475]Perceber: romanzo eroicomico By Leonardo Colombati p. 475{{cite web |url=http://www.geschichteinchronologie.ch/eu/jugoland/EncJud_juden-im-jugoland-d/EncJud_Yugoslavia-band16-kolonne871-872.gif |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930152411/http://www.geschichteinchronologie.ch/eu/jugoland/EncJud_juden-im-jugoland-d/EncJud_Yugoslavia-band16-kolonne871-872.gif |archivedate=2012-09-30 |df= }} Encyclopaedia Judaica, 1971 p. 871-2 According to other version he died in Sofia, [[Ottoman Empire]] (now [[Sofia]], [[Republic of Bulgaria]]) but his body was transferred to Üsküp and buried here.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=1_xsTvCEOISeOpuwuNkF&ct=result&id=cFAwAAAAYAAJ&dq=nathan+of+gaza+died+in+sofia&q=+died+sofia#search_anchor Restoring the Jews to their homeland: nineteen centuries in the quest for Zion, Author Joseph Adler, Publisher J. Aronson, 1997, p. 36.], {{ISBN|1568219784}}[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=208&letter=G Nathan of Ghaza, Jewish Encyclopedia online.][https://books.google.com/books?ei=kgBtTp6NGImAOpu34OMF&ct=result&id=DacvAQAAIAAJ&dq=nathan+gaza+died+in+sofia&q=sofia#search_anchor A history of the Jewish people, Authors Max Leopold Margolis, Alexander Marx, Publisher Atheneum, 1985, p. 566.], {{ISBN|0-689-70134-9}} It is presumed also, he could have died traveling from Sofia to Üsküp. It is understood that upon arriving into Üsküp that day, he immediately requested that several gravediggers construct his grave. {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = 150px | caption = | name = Patrick McKenna | occupation = Comedian, actor | years_active = 1980s–present | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|05|08}} | birth_place = [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = | spouse = {{marriage|Janis McKenna|1983}} | children = 1 | death_place = | othername = | website = http://www.PatrickMcKenna.ca | nationality = Canadian }} '''Patrick McKenna''' (born May 8, 1960) is a Canadian [[comedian]] and [[actor]]. He is best known for playing Harold Green on the [[television]] series ''[[The Red Green Show]]''.
==Early life== Patrick McKenna became interested in [[The Second City|Second City]] when a high-school teacher took him to a show at Second City Toronto. After he graduated from high school, he attended [[Sheridan College]], graduating with a business degree in 1982. To help with tuition, he worked his way to being night manager at Second City, learning how improv worked. In 1983 he auditioned successfully for the main stage. During the 1980s he tried his hand at standup and spent 5 years performing his act in Canada and the US.
One night at Second City during the late 1980s, McKenna received the acting-job offer which would change his life. Steve Smith was recruiting cast members, especially a sidekick, for his new project, ''The Red Green Show''. He had come to Second City and was scoping out the entire troupe, but when Patrick did his twitchy-nerd character, Smith knew he had his sidekick. He approached McKenna after the show, and he accepted the part. This twitchy nerd character would be seen on television screens throughout Canada and the US for the next 15 years as the lovable nephew Harold Green on ''The Red Green Show''.
==Career== McKenna's main acting role was that of Harold Green in the popular [[television]] comedy ''[[The Red Green Show]]''. He also played Marty Stephens on ''[[Traders (TV series)|Traders]]'', working alongside future Stargate SG-1 and Stargate Atlantis star, British-born Canadian actor [[David Hewlett]] and McKenna also starred in the ''[[Trudeau (film)|Trudeau]]'' miniseries.
For his work on ''Traders'' and ''The Red Green Show'', McKenna received two Gemini awards. He is the only Canadian actor to receive these for drama and comedy in the same year, winning them at the [[13th Gemini Awards]] on 4 October 1998.
McKenna was the subject of the PBS Documentary ''[[ADD & Loving it|ADD and Loving It?!]]'' In 2006 McKenna played producer Jeffrey Littleman on the short-lived CBC television series ''[[Getting Along Famously]]''. He also voices [[Iggy Arbuckle#Robear and Robert|Robear]] on ''[[Iggy Arbuckle]]''.
In 2007 he appeared in the pilot of ''[[Sabbatical (TV series)|Sabbatical]]''. He stars as Victor in indie horror film ''[[Silent But Deadly]]''.
McKenna guest starred in two episodes of ''[[Stargate SG-1]]'' playing Dr. [[List of Tau'ri characters in Stargate SG-1#Jay Felger|Jay Felger]], first in the Season 6 episode "[[The Other Guys (Stargate SG-1)|The Other Guys]]" and then in the Season 7 episode "[[Avenger 2.0 (Stargate SG-1)|Avenger 2.0]]".
In late 2011 he played the politician and [[Canadian Confederation]] leader [[Alexander Galt]] in the CBC TV movie ''John A: Birth of a Country''.
Between 2011 and 2013, McKenna was featured as a voice actor on the Teletoon animated series ''[[Crash Canyon]]''.
As of 2012, McKenna is still active in acting, live speakings, and charitable work. He occasionally can be seen as Mr. Telson on the TV series ''Wingin It'', and in the television series ''[[Hard Rock Medical]]''. He appeared in the first episode of the third season, and the first two episodes of the eighth season of ''[[Murdoch Mysteries]]'' as Detective, and later Inspector, Hamish Slorach.
==Charitable work== In recent years, McKenna has become involved with many charity organizations—including Wheelchair athletes, Adult ADHD, MS Society, Lupus Canada and McMaster Sick Kids—some of which he has personal connection.
McKenna suffered a debilitating back injury in the early 2000s that left him unable to walk for a year. He went through times being in a wheelchair and having to learn to walk again. It was from this experience that he became involved with Wheelchair athletes.
His mother, Patricia, suffers from lupus. She has been suffering from the condition since the 1970s. McKenna's friend and fellow Second City alumn [[Colin Mochrie]] and his wife, [[Debra McGrath]], are often seen helping McKenna with lupus charity fundraising.
McKenna has ADD/ADHD and was not diagnosed until he was well into his forties. He has become somewhat of spokesman on this condition in Canada through his personal struggles. McKenna and Rick Green, a writer and performer for ''The Red Green Show'', made a documentary to explain some of ADD/ADHD's positives and negatives titled "ADD and Loving It." Both men open up about how it has affected them and their relationships. McKenna's wife, Janis, is also interviewed during the documentary and goes through the diagnosing process on camera with Patrick.
==Personal life== McKenna is a member of [[Toronto]]'s ''[[The Second City]]'' comedy troupe.
McKenna's mother's name is Patricia, and he has three brothers. He married his high school sweetheart, Janis, in 1983. They have a son, Brendon, born in 1985.
Brendon McKenna was also seen in two episodes, ''Dancing with Mr. D.'' and ''The Unseen Lever'', of his father's series ''Traders'' as Marty's son, Mark Stephens.

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} {{Infobox person | name = Piotr Wilniewczyc | image = Piotr Wilniewczyc.JPG | caption = Inventor of the [[ViS]] | quotation = | birth_date = {{birth date|1887|1|31|mf=y}} | birth_place = near [[Irkutsk]], [[Russia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1960|12|23|1887|1|31|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] }} '''Piotr Wilniewczyc''' (1887–1960) was a [[Poland|Polish]] engineer and arms designer. Among his most successful designs were the [[Vis-35 (weapon)|Vis-35]] pistol, commonly known as the Radom for the arsenal in which it was produced, and the [[Pistolet maszynowy Mors|Mors]] [[submachine gun]].
== Biography == Piotr Wilniewczyc was born 31 January 1887 near [[Irkutsk]] in [[Siberia]]. He grew up in [[Vilna]] (now Vilnius, Lithuania). In 1905 he moved to [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]], and studied at the [[University of St. Petersburg]] institute of mathematics and physics. He continued his studies in the [[Lwów University of Technology|Lwów Polytechnic]] department of chemistry. In 1915 Wilniewczyc also graduated from artillery school in St. Petersburg.
In 1921 he accepted employment at the Boryszew Gunpowder Factory near [[Sochaczew]], Poland. From 1924 to 1928, Wilniewczyc also lectured at the Artillery Officers' School in [[Toruń]]. In 1928 he began work as director of the ballistics department at the [[State Arms Factories]] (''Państwowe Wytwórnie Uzbrojenia''), holding this post until [[Invasion of Poland|war broke out]] in September 1939.
His most successful project was the [[Vis-35 (weapon)|Vis-35]] pistol, a standard Polish prewar military pistol. He also designed the [[Pistolet maszynowy Mors|Mors]] [[submachine gun]], which did not enter production due to the outbreak of war. After the war, he directed a team that designed the [[PM wz. 63|Rak wz. 63]] submachine gun, completed after his death.
During the war, Wilniewczyc worked with the [[Home Army]] in [[Warsaw]], developing a silencer for the [[Sten]] gun. After the [[Warsaw Uprising]] he moved to [[Łódź]] and soon began lecturing at the [[Technical University of Łódź|Łódź Polytechnic]]. From 1948 he also worked at the reopened [[Warsaw University of Technology|Warsaw Polytechnic]].
Wilniewczyc died on 23 December 1960 and was interred at Warsaw's [[Powązki Cemetery]].
